{{Cleanup|date=January 2011}}
Following the [[Iranian presidential election, 2009|2009 Iranian presidential election]], protests against alleged [[electoral fraud]] and in support of opposition candidates [[Mir-Hossein Mousavi]] and [[Mehdi Karroubi]] occurred in [[Tehran]] and other major cities in Iran and around the world starting after the disputed presidential election on 2009 June 12<ref name="cnn1">{{cite news |title=Iran election protests turn violent |publisher=CNN |date=June 13, 2009 |url=http://www.cnn.com/2009/WORLD/meast/06/13/iran.election/index.html |accessdate=June 13, 2009}}</ref> and continued even after the inauguration of [[Mahmoud Ahmedinejad]] as [[President of Iran]] on 5 August 2009. This is a timeline of the events which occurred during [[2009 Iranian election protests|those protests]]. {{TOC limit|3}}
==2009==
===June===
====June 13–15====
In what had become the worst civil unrest in Iran in over a decade, clashes broke out between police and groups protesting the election results from early Saturday morning onward. Protests were initially mostly peaceful but became increasingly violent.<ref name="cnn1"/> Demonstrators chanted phrases such as "Down with the dictator", "Death to the dictator", and "Give us our votes back".<ref name=youth>{{cite news|first=Dudi|last=Cohen|date=June 14, 2009|accessdate=June 14, 2009|url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-3730786,00.html|title=Tehran youth: I'll never vote in Iran again}}</ref><ref name=free/> Mousavi urged for calm and asked that his supporters refrain from acts of violence.<ref name=free>{{cite news|publisher=BBC News|title=Ahmadinejad defiant on 'free' Iran poll |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/8099115.stm|date=June 13, 2009|accessdate=June 13, 2009}}</ref>
[[File:Iran election (1).jpg|thumb|Protesters in Tehran, June 13, 2009]]
Anonymous sources said that the police stormed the headquarters of the [[Islamic Iran Participation Front]] and arrested a number of people.<ref name=abc>{{cite news|title=Election Battles Turn Into Street Fights in Iran |publisher=[[ABC News]] |url=http://abcnews.go.com/International/wireStory?id=7830630 |date=June 13, 2009 |accessdate=June 13, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090616044520/http://abcnews.go.com/International/wireStory?id=7830630 |archivedate=June 16, 2009 }}</ref><ref name="reformists1">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/8099218.stm |title=Iran reformists held after street clashes |publisher=BBC News |date=2009-06-14}}</ref>
Two hundred people protested outside Iran's embassy in [[London]].<ref>{{cite news|language=French |publisher=[[Yahoo!|Yahoo! France]] |title=Manifestation devant l'ambassade d'Iran à Londres |url=http://fr.news.yahoo.com/3/20090613/twl-iran-presidentielle-gb-manifestation-ba66223.html |accessdate=June 13, 2009 |date=June 13, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5hWc6HQnu?url=http://fr.news.yahoo.com/3/20090613/twl-iran-presidentielle-gb-manifestation-ba66223.html |archivedate= June 14, 2009 }}</ref> Protests led by Iranian-Americans were also held outside the Iranian representative office in [[New York City]].<ref>{{cite web |last=Milburn |first=Ty |url=http://www.ny1.com/content/top_stories/100727/iranian-new-yorkers-protest-ahmadinejad-s-re-election/Default.aspx |title=24 Hour Local News | Top Stories | Iranian New Yorkers Protest Ahmadinejad's Re-Election |publisher=NY1 |date= |accessdate=2009-06-15 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090617064443/http://www.ny1.com/content/top_stories/100727/iranian-new-yorkers-protest-ahmadinejad-s-re-election/Default.aspx |archivedate=2009-06-17 |df= }}</ref>
[[File:Burning bus, Iranian presidential election 2009.jpg|left|thumb|Burning bus during the election protests in Tehran, June 13]]
On Sunday, protests grew considerably in scope and violence, leading [[Al Jazeera English]] to describe the situation as the "biggest unrest since the [[Iranian Revolution|1979 revolution]]". It also reported that protests seemed spontaneous without any formal organization.<ref name=al>{{cite news|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2009/06/2009613172130303995.html.|title=Poll results prompt Iran protests|publisher=[[Al Jazeera English]]|accessdate=June 13, 2009|date=June 13, 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090618073345/http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2009/06/2009613172130303995.html.|archivedate=June 18, 2009|df=}}</ref> Buses and trash cans were burned, and parked cars blocked streets and highways in Tehran and routes leading into the city. Protesters attacked shops, government offices, police stations, police vehicles, gas stations and banks.<ref name=bbc>{{cite news|title=Iran Election sparks clashes |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/8098942.stm|date=2009-06-14|accessdate=2009-06-14|publisher=BBC News}}</ref> Barricades were installed around all government ministries, embassies (there were reports of shootings outside the Russian Embassy, which supported the election results), Mehrabad and [[Imam Khomeini International Airport]], where there were scenes of large clashes with riot police. Large protests, which escalated into riots, broke out at [[Tehran University]], [[Amirkabir University]], and [[Shahid Beheshti University]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Ahmadinejad hails election as protests grow |url=http://www.cnn.com/2009/WORLD/meast/06/13/iran.election/index.html#cnnSTCVideo|accessdate=2009-06-14|publisher=BBC News |date=June 13, 2009}}</ref> Other protests occurred in [[Ahwaz]], [[Shiraz]], [[Gorgan]], [[Tabriz]], [[Rasht]], [[Babol]], [[Mashhad]], [[Isfahan]], [[Zahedan]], [[Qazvin]], [[Sari]], [[Karaj]], [[Tabriz]], [[Tonekabon|Shahsavar]], [[Orumieh]], [[Bandar Abbas]], [[Arak, Iran|Arak]], and [[Birjend]].<ref name=NCR6488>{{cite news|title=Popular uprising a stamp of rejection of sham election, display of Iranians' determination|url=http://ncr-iran.org/content/view/6488/1/|date=2009-06-14|accessdate=2009-06-14|publisher=NCR|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090618061222/http://ncr-iran.org/content/view/6488/1/|archivedate=2009-06-18|df=}}</ref> In Gorgan, protestors broke into a Basij base and killed several IRGC officials,{{citation needed|date=October 2013}} causing mass purges and attacks in the city. Since riot police are largely limited to Tehran, the IRGC and the Basij were dispatched to quell protests in other cities.
Reporters from the Italian state-owned television broadcaster [[RAI]] stated that one of its interpreters was beaten with clubs by riot police and the officers then confiscated the cameraman's tapes.<ref name=abc /> Also several [[BBC]] cameramen were beaten and arrested by [[Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps|IRGC]] officials and had their tapes confiscated.<ref name="bbc"/><ref name=bbcjamming>{{cite web|title=Stop the blocking now |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/blogs/theeditors/2009/06/stop_the_blocking_now.html|date=2009-06-14|accessdate=2009-06-14|publisher=BBC News}}</ref>

====June 16====
[[File:Tehran protests (15).jpg|thumb|upright|Protesters in Tehran, June 16]]
Thousands of people massed the streets of Tehran again.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/middle_east/8103577.stm |title=Middle East | Iran opposition keeps up pressure |publisher=BBC News |date=2009-06-16 |accessdate=2009-06-20}}</ref><ref name="nyttuesday16">{{cite news|title=Opposition in Iran Rejects Call for Partial Recount |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/06/17/world/middleeast/17iran.html | work=The New York Times | first=Nazila | last=Fathi | date=June 17, 2009 | accessdate=March 28, 2010}}</ref> A British journalist reported seeing special police keeping Basijs and demonstrators separated.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/opinion/commentators/fisk/robert-fisk-fear-has-gone-in-a-land-that-has-tasted-freedom-1706912.html|title=Robert Fisk: Fear has gone in a land that has tasted freedom|date=2009-06-17|accessdate=2009-06-17|publisher=[[The Independent]] | location=London}}</ref> Over 120 Tehran University professors who had resigned in protest of violence against students joined the protests after security forces violently raided university dormitories.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://ncr-iran.org/content/view/6509/1/|title=Iran: 120 professors resign and join sit-in by students in Tehran University|date=2009-06-16|accessdate=2009-06-16|publisher=[[National Council of Resistance of Iran]]|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090618061227/http://ncr-iran.org/content/view/6509/1/|archivedate=2009-06-18|df=}}</ref>
[[File:Tehran protest.jpg|left|A protester holds a sign reading "Be patient! The morning is coming...", June 16|thumb]]
The [[Guardian Council]] announced that it was prepared to order a partial recount, and ruled out an annulment of the vote.<ref name=nyttuesday16/> The concession was rejected by the main opposition candidate, Mir-Hossein Mousavi, demanding that a new election be held.<ref name=nyttuesday16/>
====June 17====
The [[Iranian national football team]] played against South Korea's team in Seoul on Wednesday, with some members of the Iranian team wearing green armbands in support of Mousavi.<ref>{{cite news|title=Iran's star footballers show support for Moussavi|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/1e2c6eee-5b3b-11de-be3f-00144feabdc0.html|publisher=Financial times|accessdate=June 17, 2009}}</ref>
Another demonstration was held in [[Tehran]] centering on the [[7 Tir Square]]. [[Crowd size estimation|Estimates of the number of participants]] ranged between 70,000 and 500,000.<ref name="BBCFreshRally">{{cite news|work=[[BBC News]] |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/middle_east/8104466.stm|title=Fresh rally takes place in Tehran|date=2009-06-18}}</ref>
[[File:Tehran protests 2009-06-17 19-39.jpg|thumb|upright|A woman protester with tape covering her mouth, engaging in silent protest while holding a photo of a protester casualty, Tehran, June 17]]
====June 18====
Candle-bearing protesters massed in central Tehran on Thursday near [[Toopkhaneh|Toopkhaneh square]], following a call by Mousavi to commemorate those who were killed on Monday's protests.<ref name="BBCFreshRally" /> Varying reports placed the crowd size between "tens of thousands"<ref>{{cite news|work=[[Los Angeles Times]] |url=http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/world/la-fg-iran-protests19-2009jun19,0,4249713.story|title=Iran protests continue for fourth day |date=2009-06-18 | first1=Borzou | last1=Daragahi | first2=Ramin | last2=Mostaghim | first3=Kim | last3=Murphy | accessdate=May 25, 2010}}</ref> and "more than 100,000."<ref name="june18bbc">{{cite news|work=[[BBC]] |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/8108115.stm|title=Masses mourn protesters in Iran |date=2009-06-18}}</ref> A second, simultaneous protest with several hundred participants took place near the UN headquarters, while a counter rally was held by hard line students protesting former President [[Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani]]'s role in the pro-Mousavi protests.<ref name="june18bbc" />
The Guardian Council invited the three major challengers to meet to discuss their grievances.<ref>{{cite news|work=[[New York Times]] |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/06/19/world/middleeast/19iran.html |title=Protesters Gather Again, as Iran Panel Offers Talks |date=2009-06-18 | first1=Nazila | last1=Fathi | first2=Michael | last2=Slackman | accessdate=March 28, 2010}}</ref>
====June 19====
Supreme Leader [[Ali Khamenei]] spoke about the previous protests during his scheduled television appearance.<ref name=mourn>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/middle_east/8108115.stm Masses mourn protesters in Iran]. BBC News Online. June 18, 2009</ref> He argued that "media belonging to [[Zionists]], evil media," were trying to divide the state and Western powers were casting doubts on the election.<ref name="Khamenei speech">{{cite news|title=Ruling Cleric Warns Iranian Protesters|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/06/20/world/middleeast/20iran.html |date=June 19, 2009|publisher=New York Times|author1=Nazila Fathi |author2=Alan Cowell |lastauthoramp=yes |accessdate=June 19, 2009}}</ref> He announced that he would not to be willing to give in to "illegal pressures" to change the results, and said that the opposition leaders would be "responsible for bloodshed and chaos" if they did not stop the demonstrations.<ref name="Khamenei speech"/><ref name=afp-19june>{{cite news|title=Amnesty says up to 10 dead in Iran protests|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5hmI8SkGap6fUGvyrbGIRk5oKCA9Q|date=June 19, 2009|publisher=AFP|accessdate=June 19, 2009}}</ref>
Hours after Khamenei's speech, defeated candidate Mehdi Karoubi called for election results to be cancelled."<ref name="Karoubi cancellation">{{cite news|title=Iran's Karoubi calls for election cancellation|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/latestCrisis/idUSEVA961207|date=June 19, 2009|publisher=Reuters}}</ref>
Mousavi spokesman [[Mohsen Makhmalbaf]] said "Mousavi's headquarters was wrecked by plainclothes police officers" with many staffers arrested, and Mousavi himself ordered by the Revolutionary Guard to stay silent. Makhmalbaf said his job was "to urge people to take to the streets because Mousavi could not do so directly".<ref>{{cite news|title=I speak for Mousavi. And Iran|url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2009/jun/19/iran-election-mousavi-ahmadinejad|date=June 19, 2009|author=Mohsen Makhmalbaf|publisher=The Guardian|accessdate=June 19, 2009 | location=London}}</ref>
Both houses of the [[US Congress]] condemned violence against demonstrators by the Iranian government.<ref name=obama>Stephen Collinson, [https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5ilgdyjrMe9wWMPc6rjNjGoq3eCeA Obama urges Iran to stop 'violent and unjust actions'], AFP 20-06-2009</ref>
An underground newspaper entitled خيابان, or "The Street," also printed an issue dated June 19.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/babylonbeyond/2009/06/iran-street-newspaper-distributed-by-protesters.html|title=IRAN: 'Street' newspaper is being distributed by protesters|accessdate=2009-06-29 | work=Los Angeles Times | date=June 20, 2009}}</ref>
====June 20====
[[State media|State-run]] television reported that at least 10 were killed and 100 injured on Saturday, as thousands of protesters swept into the streets of [[Tehran]], in open defiance of warnings issued Friday by Iran's Supreme Leader and Security Council. State media said 457 people had been detained over Saturday's violence. {{Citation needed|date=June 2009}}. A young Iranian woman, identified as [[Neda Soltan]],<ref>{{cite news|language=french|publisher=egoblog.net|title=Her name was Neda|url=http://egoblog.net/2009/06/21/her-name-was-neda/ | accessdate = June 21, 2009| date = June 21, 2009}}</ref> was shot by the [[Basij]] and died in front of cameras on Kargar Avenue in Tehran.<ref>{{cite news|publisher=BreakForNews.com|title=Unidentified Woman Shot Dead in Karegar Ave - 20 June 2009|url=http://breakfornews.com/KarekarAveShooting090620.htm | accessdate = June 20, 2009| date = June 20, 2009}}</ref> Highly graphic amateur videos of the killing rapidly spread [[viral video|virally]] across the internet after being posted to [[Facebook]] and [[YouTube]].<ref>{{cite news|publisher=[[YouTube]]|title=Basij shots to a young woman in Tehran's Saturday June 20th protests|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=185vPe_gROA | accessdate = June 20, 2009| date = June 20, 2009}}</ref> On 20 June – a day after Khamenei had warned of a brutal reaction if unrest continued – the Tehran ambulance service's internal radio system confirmed that at least 47 people had died, many from gunshot wounds. http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2009/dec/27/iran-tehran-ayotollah-khamenei-protests
On Saturday night, the Iranian state-run news agency [[Islamic Republic of Iran News Network|IRINN]] said an attacker had been killed earlier in the day outside Tehran at the entrance to the mausoleum that holds the body of former Supreme Leader Ayatollah [[Ruhollah Khomeini]]. The agency said the man "carrying the bomb" was killed, and there were no other casualties. [[Press TV]] was reporting that the bomber was the sole fatality, and that three other people were wounded at the shrine to Khomeini.<ref name=chaos>[http://edition.cnn.com/2009/WORLD/meast/06/20/iran.election/index.html Chaos prevails as protesters, police clash in Iranian capital], CNN 21-06-2009</ref> These claims have not been confirmed.
In a statement posted on the website of his ''Kalemeh'' newspaper, Mousavi repeated his demand for the elections results to be annulled, and charged that the fraud could destroy the country's [[republicanism]].<ref name=police>[http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2009/06/2009620184151643728.html Police crack down on Iran protests], Al Jazeera 21-06-2009</ref> An ally of Mousavi reported that the opposition leader had told his supporters that he was ready for [[martyrdom]]<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/latestCrisis/idUSHAF058781 |title=Iran's Mousavi says ready for martyrdom-witness |publisher=Reuters |date=2009-02-09 |accessdate=2009-06-20}}</ref> and had called for a general strike.<ref>{{cite news|title=Mussawi fordert Irans regime heraus|url=http://www.spiegel.de/politik/ausland/0,1518,631609,00.html|date=June 20, 2009|publisher=Der Spiegel|accessdate=June 20, 2009}}</ref> Speaker of the Parliament (Majlis) [[Ali Larijani]] declared that a significant number of people believed the official election results to be fraudulent,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.khabaronline.ir/news-11125.aspx|title=مسئولان به درخواست‌کنندگان تجمعات اجازه بدهند|publisher=Khabar online|accessdate=June 21, 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090622201020/http://www.khabaronline.ir/news-11125.aspx|archivedate=June 22, 2009|df=}}</ref> arguing that their opinion should be respected.<ref>{{cite news|title=Larijani criticizes Guardian Council, IRIB|url=http://www.presstv.ir/detail.aspx?id=98645&sectionid=351020101|date=June 21, 2009|accessdate=June 21, 2009|publisher=Press TV|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090623222555/http://www.presstv.ir/detail.aspx?id=98645&sectionid=351020101|archivedate=June 23, 2009|df=}}</ref>
State television quoted a council spokesman as saying that the Guardian Council had expressed its readiness to "randomly" recount up to 10 per cent of the ballots.<ref name=police/>
Worldwide solidarity protests took place in [[New York City]], [[Los Angeles]], at the gates of the [[White House]],<ref>[https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5h0idGjtItI7TULclixzz8fKlagcA Thousands rally to support reform demos in Iran], AFP 20-06-2009</ref> outside of [[Paris]] and in [[Brussels]].<ref>[https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5gRpO_tqRaYfcIcQGqfzPKTNhL1jg Pro-Iran protests held in US cities], AFP 20-06-2009</ref> US-based human rights group [[Human Rights Watch]] and [[US President]] [[Barack Obama]] both issued statements urging the Iranian government to end violence against protesters.<ref name=chaos/><ref>[https://www.reuters.com/article/topNews/idUSTRE55J1QP20090620 Western rights group calls on Iran to end crackdown], Reuters 20-06-2009</ref>
====June 21====
Iranian Foreign Minister [[Manouchehr Mottaki]] rebuked Britain, France and Germany for raising questions about reports of voting irregularities. Mottaki charged France with taking "treacherous and unjust approaches," and accused Britain of flying intelligence agents into Iran before the election to interfere with the vote. The election, he insisted, was a "very transparent competition." British Foreign Secretary [[David Miliband]] categorically denied the charge against his country, adding: "This can only damage Iran's standing in the eyes of the world."<ref name=eerie>[https://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20090621/ap_on_re_mi_ea/ml_iran_election In Tehran, an eerie calm as death toll jumps to 19], Associated Press (reprinted in Yahoo! News 21-06-2009)</ref>
An Iranian official at the [[Ministry of Culture and Islamic Guidance]] announced the expulsion of [[BBC]] Tehran correspondent Jon Leyne but said the BBC office in Tehran would remain open. The semi-official [[Fars News Agency]], which said Leyne must leave within 24 hours, explained that he was accused of "dispatching fabricated news and reports" and "ignoring neutrality in news," as well as "supporting rioters and trampling the Iranian nation's rights."<ref>Hashem Kalantari and Fredrik Dahl, [https://www.reuters.com/article/newsMaps/idUSTRE55K15S20090621 Iran expels BBC correspondent: official], Reuters 21-06-2009</ref> Furthermore, Iranian officials detained Iranian-born, Canadian citizen and [[Newsweek]] journalist [[Maziar Bahari]].<ref>[http://www.newsweek.com/id/203015 Newsweek Reporter Detained.] [[Newsweek]]. Retrieved 21 June 2009.</ref> Campaign group Reporters Without Borders says 23 local journalists and bloggers have been arrested over the past week.
While the streets have generally been quiet in Tehran, the daughter of Hashemi Rafsanjani and four other relatives have reportedly been jailed. Security forces have labeled protesters as "terrorists" and demonstrators condemned the harsh tactics of government-backed militias. Officials have reiterated that they are prepared to use force against protesters. Reuters reported that Iran Police Chief Ismail Ahmadi Moghaddam told opposition leader Mousavi that "bandits are acting in the shadow of the illegal atmosphere created by you."<ref>{{cite news|title=Iran calms, but daughter of top Iranian cleric reportedly arrested|url=http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/world/la-fg-iran-arrests22-2009jun22,0,2269803.story|accessdate=June 21, 2009 | work=Los Angeles Times | first1=Jeffrey | last1=Fleishman | first2=Ramin | last2=Mostaghim | date=June 22, 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Iran clerics criticize leadership over poll unrest|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/worldNews/idUSTRE55F54520090621|accessdate=June 21, 2009 | work=Reuters | date=June 21, 2009}}</ref>
[[Press TV]], an Iranian English-language news channel funded by the Iranian Government, reported that the Guardian Council admitted that there were some irregularities in the election, specifically that in over 50 cities more votes were cast than there were eligible voters. The council's spokesman, Abbas-Ali Kadkhodaei, stated that, "Statistics provided by [[Mohsen Rezaee|Mohsen Rezaei]] in which he claims more than 100% of those eligible have cast their ballot in 170 cities are not accurate -- the incident has happened in only 50 cities." The council also reported that these regularities would affect approximately 3 million votes, but stated that, "it has yet to be determined whether the amount is decisive in the election results."<ref>[http://www.presstv.ir/detail/98711.htm?sectionid=351020101 Guardian Council: Over 100% voted in 50 cities]. [[Press TV]]. Retrieved 21 June 2009.</ref>
====June 22====
The Guardian Council, the body in charge of supervising and certifying the elections in Iran, declared the incumbent President Ahmadinejad winner after dismissing the vote challenges, according to a front-page report on CNN.com. The report said that PressTV, a semi-state run television network in the nation announced the decision via a spokesperson for the group. They said that while they agreed that in up to 50 cities votes were higher than those eligible to vote, but that it was not enough to result in anything beyond further investigations. [http://www.cnn.com/2009/WORLD/meast/06/21/iran.election/index.html]
Speaking at a news conference on Monday, foreign ministry spokesman [[Hassan Qashqavi]] accused Western governments of explicitly backing violent protests aimed at undermining the stability of Iran's Islamic Republic. He said the West was acting in an "anti-democratic" manner, instead praising Iran's commitment to democracy and stressing once again that the results of the presidential election were unimpeachable. Iran has strongly criticised the US and UK governments in recent days, and Mr Qashqavi reserved special scorn for the [[BBC]] and for the [[Voice of America]] network, which he called "government channels". He spoke as Tehran remained tense but quiet amid heavy security aimed at preventing new protests against the result of Iran's presidential election. Mr [[Mousavi]] has told his supporters, who have taken to the streets in their tens of thousands for more than a week, to continue their protests but not to put their lives in danger.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/8112176.stm|title=West 'seeks Iran disintegration'|date=2009-06-22|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=2009-06-29}}</ref>
[[The Guardian]]'s live blog reported that at approximately 1:30 pm, General [[Ali Fazli]], the newly appointed commander of the Revolutionary Guards in Tehran province, has been arrested for refusing to carry Khamenei's order to use force against demonstrators.<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/news/blog/2009/jun/22/iran-ayatollah-ali-khamenei Iran in crisis: live]. [[The Guardian]]. Retrieved 22 June 2009.</ref>
At 4:30 pm Tehran time, Iran's ambassador to London was summoned to the Foreign Office and told that Khamenei's remarks were unacceptable. British Prime Minister [[Gordon Brown]] later condemned the "repression" and "brutality" used against the protesters. At approximately the same time the British Embassy in Tehran announced they were evacuating the families of embassy staff members and issued a [[travel advisory]] against visiting Iran. The Foreign Office noted that, "further violence is possible," but said it did not believe it was necessary for British nationals already in Iran to leave the country.<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/world/2009/jun/22/iran-embassy-staff-families-evacuated Britain evacuates families of embassy staff in Iran] [[The Guardian]] Published 22 June 2009 17.07 BST. Retrieved 22 June 2009.</ref>
According to the [[BBC]], 1,000 protesters gathered at Haft-e Tir Square in defiance of a warning by the Revolutionary Guard that they would crack down hard on additional protests. Riot police fired tear gas to disperse the crowd.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/8112812.stm|title= Police break up new Tehran rally|date=2009-06-22|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=2009-06-29}}</ref>
====June 23====
According to social networking sites such as [[Twitter]] and online newspapers such as [[The Huffington Post]], many [[Iran]]ians have avoided the streets in fear of combat with the [[Basij]].{{Citation needed|date=July 2009}} Unconfirmed reports of moderate sized gathering were later proven by photography and video.{{Citation needed|date=July 2009}}
[[Barack Obama|U.S. President Obama]] condemned the use of violence in [[Iran]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/31507917 |title=Obama ratchets up language on Iran violence|date=23 June 2009|work=[[msnbc.com]]|accessdate=26 November 2009}}</ref> and made a reference to [[Death of Neda Agha-Soltan|Neda]] who was shot to death during a rally in [[Tehran]] by an unknown [[Basij]] [[sniper]]. It was also reported by the Iranian-government funded news service [[Press TV]] that [[Mahmoud Ahmadinejad]] would be sworn in by the [[Parliament of Iran]] either in late July or early August.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.presstv.ir/detail.aspx?id=98830&sectionid=351020101|title=Iran sets date for Ahmadinejad to take oath of office|date=23 June 2009|work=[[Press TV]]|accessdate=26 November 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090626043830/http://www.presstv.ir/detail.aspx?id=98830&sectionid=351020101|archivedate=26 June 2009|df=}}</ref>
Iranians continued to gather in groups of several hundred, while [[Basij]] militants used tear gas to disperse protesters.{{Citation needed|date=July 2009}} The Iranian government stated that it would expel British diplomats for "unconventional behavior."{{Citation needed|date=July 2009}}
The Guardian reported that at least four Iranian players from the national soccer team who wore green armbands during the [[2010 FIFA World Cup qualification - AFC Fourth Round|fourth round World Cup qualifying match]] in Seoul received "life bans".<ref name="guardianSoccer">{{Cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2009/jun/23/iran-football-protest-ban| title=Iran bans election protest footballers| first=Robert| last=Tait| date=June 23, 2009| accessdate=July 14, 2009 | work=The Guardian | location=London}}</ref> The New York Times later reported that FIFA had asked the players to remove the armbands at halftime because the governing body prohibits any expressions that can be interpreted as political. Afshin Ghotbi, the coach of the team at the time, stated "The stories on the players are false and rumors, The [Iranian Football Federation] has not taken any official stand on this issue. We only saw the story in the international media."<ref name="NYTGoal">{{cite news| url=http://goal.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/06/26/iran-did-not-suspend-players-coach-says/| title=Iran Did Not Suspend Players, Coach Says| date=June 26, 2009| first=Jack| last=Bell| accessdate=July 14, 2009 | work=The New York Times}}</ref><ref name="GOAL.com">{{Cite news| title=FIFA To Investigate Iran Over Alleged Player 'Punishment'| url=https://sports.yahoo.com/sow/news?slug=goal_fifa_to_investigate&prov=goal&type=lgns| date=June 26, 2009| first=Mike| last=Maguire| publisher=GOAL.com| accessdate=July 14, 2009}}</ref> Furthermore, the claim that they soccer players wore wristbands "in support of Mousavi" was manufactured by the Western media, without recognizing that green was part of the official uniform of the team (as well as the flag) and the same players also had green shirt collars and green designs on their shirt and socks, as evident in the photographs of the players.
According to some sources{{Who|date=July 2009}}, the people of Kurdistan province started a protest against the treatment of protesters in Tehran, with its starting point in the city of [[Saqqez]]. Protests consisted of rallies and business strikes in this area.<ref>{{cite web|script-title=fa:آغازاعتصاب عمومی در کردستان |language=Persian| url=http://www.dw-world.de/dw/article/0,,4418070,00.html}}</ref>{{Unreliable source?|date=July 2009}}<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rawanews.com/details.aspx?=News&ID=505&Babat=1|script-title=fa:مانگرتنه‌كه‌ سه‌راسه‌ریه‌كه‌ی كوردستان له‌ ده‌روازه‌ی سه‌قزه‌وه‌ ده‌ستی پێكرد|date=2009-06-23|publisher=Rawa News|language=persian|accessdate=2009-06-29}}</ref>{{Unreliable source?|date=July 2009}}
====June 24====
Former Iranian President [[Mohammad Khatami]] reportedly made a call for peaceful mass stand-ins in bazaars across Iran, with the aim of disrupting commerce while avoiding the violent police crackdowns which have accompanied the more overt protests and riots.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://narcosphere.narconews.com/thefield/bazaar-comrades|title=To the Bazaar, Comrades!|accessdate=2009-06-29}}</ref>
A caller into the [[CNN]] newsroom who is a female Iranian citizen claimed that in [[Baharestan]] Square, [[Basij]] forces shot bullets into the crowd.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=02qY9K2iOqA |title=Broadcast Yourself |publisher=YouTube |date=2009-06-24 |accessdate=2010-03-30}}</ref> She also claimed that students and old men alike were being beaten by these guards. In addition, it was believed that these [[Basij]] guards did not speak [[Persian language|Persian]] because they did not understand nor did they respond to the cries from the protesters. She reported that these [[Basij]] militia-men came out of a local [[mosque]] by the hundreds to violently attack protesters.
On this day numerous violent confrontations with the [[Basij]] were reported. It seems as if the violence has started again in [[Tehran]], but again, as of this date, these reports are confirmed with few photos and videos.
There were also reports of protesters at the Iranian Parliament building coming under sniper fire from Basiji. While Wednesday's protests were relatively small in terms of the numbers of people involved, they are said to have been some of the bloodiest during the unrest. Iranian dissidents claim the day's violence raised the death toll to 249 the last ten days.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2009/jun/25/opposition-alters-tactics-to-avoid-protest-deaths/|title=Iran protesters alter tactics to avoid death|date=2009-06-25|publisher=The Washington Times|accessdate=2009-06-29}}</ref>
In what has been interpreted as a sign of divisions within the Iranian government, it was reported that 185 of the 290 Iranian Members of Parliament invited to attend Ahmadinejad's Wednesday night victory celebration rejected their invitations.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/8118139.stm|title= MPs 'snub' Ahmadinejad poll party|date=2009-06-25|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=2009-06-29}}</ref>
====June 25====
Mirhossein Mousavi remained defiant, denouncing the election as an "evil conspiracy," and refusing to "withdraw [his protests] for even one moment."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://andrewsullivan.theatlantic.com/the_daily_dish/2009/06/mousavis-graceful-resistance.html|title=Mousavi's Graceful Resistance|date=2009-06-25|publisher=Andrew Sullivan - The Atlantic|accessdate=2009-06-29}}</ref>
Compared to the earlier violence, June 25 was the calmest day that Tehran had seen in nearly two weeks. A source for [[The Guardian (UK)|The Guardian]] reported that this was likely due, at least in part, to the national university entrance exams being conducted on that day, in which 1.5 million young Iranians participated.<ref name="guardian-iran-crisis">{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/news/blog/2009/jun/25/iran-crisis|title=Iran crisis: live|publisher=The Guardian|accessdate=2009-06-29 | location=London | first=Daniel | last=Nasaw | date=June 25, 2009}}</ref>
Another opposition candidate, [[Mahdi Karroubi]], postponed a vigil of mourning for the victims scheduled for June 25, pushing the date back at least a week. According to Karroubi's website, the memorial service was delayed because the authorities had not granted the organizers permission to hold the rally.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2009/06/25/world/main5112528.shtml|title=Mousavi Faces Heat, But Vows Not To Crack|date=2009-06-25|publisher=CBS News|accessdate=2009-06-29}}</ref>
Despite the relative quiet, there were still a few incidents. A group of mourners attempted to visit the grave of Neda Agha Soltan, but were turned away by riot police. Those who refused the order to disperse or were seen carrying green signs were arrested.<ref name="guardian-iran-crisis" /> Clashes were also reported in and around Enghelab square, a site of previous violence. Protesters were said to have come from two sides and tried to drive the police from the square. Youths reportedly threw stones at blockades and set a bus on fire, and gunfire was reported in the area.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://andrewsullivan.theatlantic.com/the_daily_dish/2009/06/livetweeting-the-revolution-day-10.html|title=Live-Tweeting The Revolution: Week 2|date=2009-06-28|publisher=The Atlantic|accessdate=2009-06-29}}</ref>
The day also saw the releases of a number of prominent Iranians who had been arrested for their parts in the opposition. According to Human Rights Watch, sixty-six of the seventy Iranian professors arrested the previous night were released from jail. Also freed were Alireza Beheshti, editor-in-chief of the pro-Mousavi newspaper Kalameh, and a photographer from the citizen journalist organization [[Demotix]].<ref name="guardian-iran-crisis" />
====June 26====
[[File:Iranian victims balloon day.jpg|thumb|People all over the world released green balloons into the sky on June 26, 2009]] On 26 June about 150 people gathered outside the [[Embassy of Iran in Stockholm|Iranian embassy in Stockholm]], [[Sweden]], to protest against the Islamic republic regime.<ref name=ap>{{Cite news |last=Nordström |first=Louise |title=Protesters break into Iranian embassy in Sweden |newspaper=[[Associated Press]] |publication-place=Stockholm |date=26 June 2009 |url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5j9ibO-wUz8OHIaKAVt5W19tgGHMgD992GQ380 |accessdate=2009-06-26 |postscript=.}}</ref> Some of the protesters managed to enter the embassy building, where they engaged in fighting with the embassy's personnel.<ref name=ap/> According to the police, one member of the embassy staff was injured in the clashes.<ref name=ap/> In addition, a few of the protesters were injured according to the organizers.<ref name=ap/> The police later managed to evict the demonstrators from the building and arrested one person.<ref name=ap/>
Ayatollah [[Ahmed Khatami]], a senior cleric [[Government of Iran|of Islamic republic]] called for pro-democracy protest leaders to be punished "without mercy" including execution for some. Khatami stated that "anyone who takes up arms to fight with [[An-Nas|the people]], they are worthy of execution," and "those who disturbed the peace and destroyed public property were 'at war with God'" and "should be 'dealt with without mercy'".<ref name=nomercy>{{Cite news |title=Call to execute Iran protest chiefs |newspaper=Press Association |url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/feedarticle/8579273 |date=June 26, 2009 | location=London | accessdate=March 28, 2010 |postscript=.}}</ref>
People across the world released green balloons in what would be called "Balloon Day" in support of the protesters.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://thelede.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/06/26/latest-updates-on-irans-disputed-election-7/?pagemode=print|title=June 26: Updates on Iran's Disputed Election|publisher=The New York Times|accessdate=7 November 2009 | first=Robert | last=Mackey | date=June 26, 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2009/06/26/iran-uprising-live-bloggi_n_221270.html|title=Iran Uprising Live-Blogging (Friday June 26)|publisher=The Huffington Post|accessdate=7 November 2009|first=Nico|last=Pitney|authorlink=Nico Pitney|date=June 26, 2009}}</ref>
Mousavi instructed via his [[Facebook]] page: : "Ok, now all the world are going to show their supports to Iranians… This Friday, We all are going to send GREEN BALLOONS to the sky to show that now ALL PEOPLE OF THE WORLD ARE IRANIAN. On 9/11 everybody was American, NOW THE WORLD IS IRANIAN."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.starboardbroadside.com/2009/06/tomorrow-is-green-balloon-day.html|title=Tomorrow is Green Balloon Day|accessdate=7 November 2009}}</ref>
====June 27====
According to Human Rights Watch, Basijis carried out nighttime raids, destroying property and beating citizens, in attempts to stop the rooftop protest calls of "Allahu akbar."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://moriab.blogspot.com/2009/06/for-immediate-release-iran-night-raids.html |title=Iran Watch Canada |publisher=Moriab.blogspot.com |date=2009-06-27 |accessdate=2010-03-30}}</ref>
At Tehran University, students held a small, candlelight vigil in memory of those killed in the two weeks of unrest. The vigil apparently was peaceful, and proceeded without incident.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2009/06/27/iran-uprising-live-bloggi_n_221809.html |title=Iran Uprising Live-Blogging (Saturday June 27) |publisher=Huffingtonpost.com |date= June 27, 2009|accessdate=2010-03-30 |first=Nico |last=Pitney}}</ref>
There were mourning at the [[Behesht-e Zahra]] Cemetery at [[Neda Agha-Soltan]]'s grave site.<ref>{{cite web|author=27 juni 2009 |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DMn4_GaVdRo |title=families go to Behesht Zahra for Martyres and NEDA |publisher=YouTube |date= |accessdate=2010-03-30}}</ref>
====June 28====
Responding to [[Mir Hossein Mousavi]]'s appeal, Iranian government legally approved a Sunday June 28, 2009, (or Tir 7th 1388 [[Anno Persico]]) peaceful prayer gathering at 6{{nbsp}}pm mourning those killed during the 2009 post-election clashes at the [[Qoba Mosque]] on Ghoba Alley<ref>{{cite web|url=http://wikimapia.org/1767515/fa/ghoba-street |title=ghoba street تهران |publisher=Wikimapia.org |date= |accessdate=2010-03-30}}</ref> (North of Hosseinie Ershad Mosque on Doktor Ali-ye Shariati) in Tehran. Diplomats from Muslim and Arab countries may attend. The government promised not to hurt the peaceful mourners present.
Snipers and intelligence officers are seen on the roofs near Ghoba, a unit of Anti-Riot Police warned people to leave, military helicopters hovering in the sky.
Thousands of people are gathered around the Ghoba-Shariati neighborhood.
An estimated 5,000 protesters marched slowly and silently through Tehran Sunday. Government was reportedly allowing demonstration.
The large crowd shouted "Ya [[Hussein]]" in a YouTube footage. A YouTube footage shows that [[Mehdi Karroubi]] entered the crowd at the Ghoba Mosque.<ref>{{cite web|author=28 juni 2009 |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rgUvDmcwmWU |title=حضور کروبی در اعتراضات مردمی روبه روی مسجد قبا |publisher=YouTube |date=2009-06-26 |accessdate=2010-03-30}}</ref> One witness reported at 8:30{{nbsp}}pm that [[Mohammad Khatami]] and [[Mir Hossein Mousavi]] are reportedly seen earlier at the Mosque. However, another witness said that [[Alireza Beheshti]], son of [[Mohammad Beheshti]] told the crowd that Mousavi was prevented from coming. [[Faezeh Hashemi]] was seen with people that ringed around the banner outside of the Mosque door. The slogans were: "Salam bar Beheshti, Dorood bar Mousavi." [[Mostafa Malekian]] stood in the Ghoba alley with the crowd and sported victory signs.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://parsine.com/pages/?cid=8684 |accessdate=June 28, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090719003416/http://parsine.com/pages/?cid=8684 |archivedate=July 19, 2009 }}</ref> [[Reza Attaran]] also joined the crowd, wearing a green T-shirt.<ref>{{cite web|author=28 juni 2009 |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rNvUGCIRZ_4 |title=Reza Attaran Popular TV & Cinema Actor & Director in ghoba رضا عطاران مسجد قبا |publisher=YouTube |date= |accessdate=2010-03-30}}</ref> Also attending the gathering was [[Hojjat al-Islam]] [[Hadi Ghaffari]].
Because the Shariati Street entrance of Ghoba Alley and the other end were both blocked by barriers, about 2000 mourners packed in the alley, under surveillance of sharpshooters and heavy police presence, especially those fully deployed along Shariati Street. A witness reported that police used tear gas to disperse the people at the northern end of the Ghoba Alley.
There are Facebook posters who claimed to have attended the Ghoba gathering who disputed that there was serious clashes, claiming that the exit towards the United Nations office (which is at the northern end of Ghoba Alley) was peaceful and free of tear gassing or clashes. This claim, along with those of serious clashes, cannot be verified.
All YouTube postings that shows Ghoba setting are peaceful so far, including one with the crowd surrounding [[Alireza Beheshti]], who spoke via a loudspeaker, and was watched by a police officer behind. Beheshti conveyed to the crowd a message delivered by Mousavi over the phone. On the same day, there are new YouTube postings of some street (allegedly on Shariati Street leading to Ghoba Alley) marches with "[[Marg bar diktator]]" (death to dictator) shouted in unison, and some with smoldering objects and gunshots dispersing rioters. But these were clearly not shot at the narrow alley of Ghoba, and not necessarily on Sunday the 28th. The safety in the surrounding of a historical mosque, coinciding with an important memorial date in the Islamic Republic seem to have given police forces and the protesters such an uneasy moment of truce and standstill. This matches the pattern throughout centuries of Islamic history in which religiously-sanctioned gatherings became moments of freedom of political expression, and in which political dissents became symbiotic with a community held together by common interpretation of faith, which secular authorities had difficulties in outlawing.<ref>{{cite web|author=28 juni 2009 |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UcvfXKe1y30 |title=June 28 Iranians rally at Ghoba Mosque (also spelled Qoba) on Shariati Street, Tehran |publisher=YouTube |date=2009-06-28 |accessdate=2010-03-30}}</ref> This has led to some witnesses to urge the Muslims among the Greens to pray silently in large numbers at mosques during prayer hours, especially on Fridays, as a silent protest against the government's prohibition on any gathering.
Despite this, the government's arrest of 8 British embassy employees (with 4 later released) is another indicator of its readiness to intimidate the international community. Khamenei has issued a statement warning "both sides"<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2009/WORLD/meast/06/28/iran.demonstration/index.html |title=Thousands demonstrate silently in Tehran |publisher=CNN.com |date= June 28, 2009|accessdate=2010-03-30}}</ref> not to provoke each other, hinting that further wanton police brutality is perceived by the Supreme Leader, if not by Ahmadinejad's faction, to be costly for the regime's shaky rule.
<gallery> File:Ghoba1.jpg| File:Ghoba2.jpg| File:Ghoba3.jpg| </gallery>
The Sunday June 28 large gathering outside the [[Qoba Mosque]] in Tehran. And YouTube footage of the gathering outside Ghoba:<ref>{{cite web|author=28 juni 2009 |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5v-OOpUbkm8 |title=مسجد قبا-شریعتی-هفتم تیر 88 |publisher=YouTube |date= |accessdate=2010-03-30}}</ref>
As early as Tehran time 7{{nbsp}}pm, most English mainstream media, including Washington Times and Al Jazeera,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2009/06/2009628192214829335.html |title=Middle East - Iranian police 'beat protesters' |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date=2009-07-30 |accessdate=2010-03-30}}</ref> reported "police clashing with 3000 protesters around Ghoba", but cited the lack of verifiable accounts from Tehran due to government press control. Injuries were reported, among them an elderly woman who was allegedly beaten by police. Her beating reportedly enraged nearby protestors, who attacked the police in turn<ref>[http://www.chron.com/disp/story.mpl/ap/top/all/6501464.html ]{{Dead link|date=March 2010}}</ref>
A Sunday June 28 YouTube posting shows a riot raging in a northern Tehran neighborhood with the [[Alborz]] Mountain in the backdrop, which was on an unconfirmed date around sunset. The entire neighborhood was shrouded in smoke. Flame was visible on a street nearby. And the video camera, viewing from a tall building, could record a uniformed armed policeman randomly shooting into the streets.<ref>{{cite web|author=28 juni 2009 |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0EgJwm-IlNQ |title=28 June - Tehran - last News |publisher=YouTube |date= |accessdate=2010-03-30}}</ref>
However, by midnight Tehran time, CNN described the Ghoba protest as "silent", with peaceful end. The Iranian government-funded [[Press TV]] also described the event as "silent", consisting of "hundreds" of people that are admittedly "Mousavi supporters" commemorating the 1981 martyrdom of [[Mohammad Beheshti]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.presstv.ir/detail.aspx?id=99288&sectionid=351020101 |title=Mousavi supporters join Beheshti commemorators |publisher=Presstv.ir |date= |accessdate=2010-03-30 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090701111805/http://www.presstv.ir/detail.aspx?id=99288&sectionid=351020101 |archivedate=2009-07-01 |df= }}</ref>
====June 29====
In Paris, thousands of demonstrators took to the streets in a show of solidarity with the Iranians.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.flickr.com/photos/sachaqs/sets/72157620539995973/ |title=#IranElection Paris rally - june 28, 2009 - a set on Flickr |publisher=Flickr.com |date=2009-06-28 |accessdate=2010-03-30}}</ref>
Meanwhile, Egyptian security forces shut down a scheduled solidarity march through the streets of Cairo, planned in honor of Neda Agha Soltan. Egyptian dissidents accused their government of hypocrisy, for having denounced the Iranian regime's repressive actions only days before banning the march.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/babylonbeyond/2009/06/egypt-marsh-showing-solidarity-with-iranian-martyr-banned.html |title=EGYPT: Police shut down Iran solidarity march | Babylon & Beyond | Los Angeles Times |publisher=Latimesblogs.latimes.com |date=2009-06-29 |accessdate=2010-03-30}}</ref>
On the floor of the Iranian Parliament, a physical confrontation broke out between MP Pezeshkian, who had urged the regime to show restraint, and hard-line MPs.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://translate.google.com/translate?u=http%3A//www.baztabonline.com/Default%2Cfa-IR%2CBaztabOnline%2CContent%2CNewsDetail%2CKey%2C15345.aspx&hl=en&langpair=auto%7Cen&tbb=1&ie=UTF-8 |title=Google Translate |publisher=Translate.google.com |date= |accessdate=2010-03-30}}</ref>
Signs of unrest continued today. Motorists in Tehran beeped their horns to signal their support for Mousavi, prompting basiji patrols to slash tires and break windshields. Meanwhile, in response to rumors of a human chain being formed, Tehran police massed at Valieasr Street to stop demonstrators from assembling.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2009/06/29/iran-uprising-live-bloggi_n_222087.html |title=Iran Uprising Live-Blogging (Monday June 29) |publisher=Huffingtonpost.com |date=2009-06-30 |accessdate=2010-03-30 |first=Nico |last=Pitney}}</ref> On this night, the rooftop chants of "Allahu akbar" continued.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2009/06/30/iran-uprising-live-bloggi_n_222970.html |title=Iran Uprising Live-Blogging (Tuesday June 30) |publisher=Huffingtonpost.com |date= June 30, 2009|accessdate=2010-03-30 |first=Nico |last=Pitney}}</ref>
The Guardian Council reaffirmed Ahmadinejad's victory after recounting 10% of the votes. Upon the announcement of this news, protesters once again took to the streets of Tehran, and clashes were reported in the city. Although the police cleared the streets relatively quickly, citizens throughout the capital resumed the shouting of revolutionary slogans from the rooftops.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/06/30/world/middleeast/30iran.html | work=The New York Times | title=Iran Council Certifies Ahmadinejad Victory | first=Michael | last=Slackman | date=June 30, 2009 | accessdate=March 28, 2010}}</ref>
====June 30====
It is reported that dissidents in Tehran, in response to the closing of newspapers, have started writing anti-government graffiti on walls throughout the city.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://moriab.blogspot.com/ |title=Iran Watch Canada |publisher=Moriab.blogspot.com |date= |accessdate=2010-03-30}}</ref>
A crowd of over 2,000 people gathered at a courthouse in [[Uromieh]] seeking information about jailed relatives. No protest activity or violence was reported at this gathering.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://thelede.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/06/30/june-30-latest-updates-on-irans-post-election-turmoil/ | work=The New York Times | first=Rogene | last=Fisher | date=June 30, 2009 | accessdate=March 28, 2010 | title=June 30: Latest Updates on Iran's Post-Election Turmoil}}</ref>
Many expatriates from [[Muslim countries]] expressed that they wish to visit the [[Behesht-e Zahra]] Cemetery in peace, or at least as close to the site of [[Neda Agha-Soltan]]'s first burial site as possible on Saturday-Sunday, July 4–5, the 2-week anniversary of her death, since the martyred woman wasn't given a proper Muslim funeral.
On the date of Ghoba, although some expatriates expressed that they would like to attend the Mosque gathering to show faith to Allah, the Ahmadinejad regime arrested 9 British diplomats as soon as they caught wind that certain Iranian-born British diplomats might be attending. Now most of the British diplomats were released under international pressure. But this{{Which|date=July 2009}} Iranian-born British diplomat is still under interrogation.
Recently, because Ahmadinejad has openly insulted the Prophet's two Sahaba,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.alarabiya.net/articles/2009/07/02/77608.html|title=Ahmadinejad unwelcome in Egypt: lawyer|publisher=[[Al Arabiya]] News Network|accessdate=August 23, 2009}}</ref> he has drawn much anger from the Ikhwan al-Muslimin in Egypt, and much contempt from even [[Hosni Mubarak]]. Mubarak pointed out, he or the King of Saudi Arabia would never insult the [[Shia]] faith in such a manner. {{Citation needed|date=July 2009}}
===July===
====July 2====
Thursday, July 2, thousands of relatives of dead protesters marched towards the [[Behesht-e Zahra]] cemetery, where mass graves were set aside for the dead, and where [[Neda Agha-Soltan]] is buried. These mourners were reportedly frustrated by the police.<ref>{{cite web|author=2 juli 2009 |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Gik9pHVyzhs |title=Tehran July 2 |publisher=YouTube |date=2009-07-01 |accessdate=2010-03-30}}</ref>
====July 4====
Thousands mourn Neda Agha-Soltan at Behesht Cemetery, Tehran. Her grave was strewn with rose petals, and adorned with the slogan "We Are Neda".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.demotix.com/news/mourning-dead-tehran |title=Mourning the dead in Tehran |publisher=Demotix.com |date=2009-06-30 |accessdate=2010-03-30}}</ref><ref>http://www.demotix.com/sites/default/files/imagecache/large_652x488_scaled/photos/99606.jpg</ref><ref>http://www.demotix.com/sites/default/files/imagecache/large_652x488_scaled/photos/99605.jpg</ref><ref>http://www.demotix.com/sites/default/files/imagecache/large_652x488_scaled/photos/99602.jpg</ref> New YouTube video surfaced on July 3 of the moment before Neda was shot. Video was filmed on roof top. Even though Khosravi Street was not directly filled with violence, it was certainly not far from the view of bike-riding Basijis. The shot that killed her was not the only shot heard in the video, though the last.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AIyLCOSDIlo |title=Broadcast Yourself |publisher=YouTube |date= |accessdate=2010-03-30}}</ref> It was apparent that the black-veiled woman (apparently Neda) accompanied by the blue-shirted old man (apparently Panahi), was shot by the bike-riding Basijis shooting at the "Marg bar diktator!" shouters, who were not close, but fully within view of the walking woman. This observation is in sharp contrast to the Iranian government's explanation that Neda's shooting was carefully set up by [[Arash Hejazi]]. If Neda's death was so carefully set up, the dozens of other violent deaths in Tehran in these few weeks can also be likewise explained, while the police and Basijis were the only people evidently armed with fire weapons, and were caught on films smashing private properties without provocation. It is also contrary to the account that the site of her shooting is entirely out of the range of rioting streets. What this video can not show, is whether there was any armed bike-riders going out of their way from the rioting street behind, to attack the woman at close range.
The Assembly of Teachers and Scientists at the [[Qom]] School for Shiite Clerics declared the 2009 election in which Ahmadinejad won "illegitimate".<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/07/05/world/middleeast/05iran.html | work=The New York Times | title=Clerical Leaders Defy Ayatollah on Iran Election | first1=Michael | last1=Slackman | first2=Nazila | last2=Fathi | date=July 5, 2009 | accessdate=May 25, 2010}}</ref>
====July 8====
Prominent Iranian lawyer [[Mohammad Ali Dadkhah]] was reportedly arrested, along with a number of others, in [[Tehran]] on 8 July 2009. He is said to have provided legal representation for some of the hundreds of people arrested following the June 2009 election.<ref name="BBC20090709">{{cite news |date= 209-07-09|title=Iran police disperse protesters |publisher=BBC News|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/8141873.stm|accessdate=2009-07-09}}</ref>
====July 9====
[[File:A shot of the demonstration of 18-Tir.JPG|thumb|Demonstrations on the anniversary of 1999 student protests, July 09]] This date, being an anniversary of [[Iran student protests, July 1999|18 Tir Massacre]], had been predicted to be a day of massive protests in Tehran. Indeed, protests broke out, with about 700 people chanting "Death to dictator!" in front of Tehran University. Other protest, by about 200 people took place at Vali-e Asr Street. Both protests were dispersed by police using batons and tear gas, however protesters managed to regroup in other places again.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB124714734408618155|title=Hundreds Defy Authorities and Protest in Iran|publisher=Wall Street Journal|date=2009-07-09 | first=Farnaz | last=Fassihi}}</ref>
Security operations against protests are difficult, as vast areas of Iranian territory were covered with [[dust storm]], including Tehran, where many offices and schools had to be closed.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/8139007.stm|title=Iran hit by sandstorm pollution|publisher=BBC News|date=2009-07-07}} And also several university dormitories (such as the dorms of university of Amirkabir(Polytechnic) of Tehran, a highly ranked university of various types of engineering, were raided by the Basij militiamen, crucially beating the students in their rooms at about 2{{nbsp}}am and demolishing their belongings.</ref>
"The demonstrators made a moral point. They told the government in no uncertain terms they are still there and not going away," said an Iranian analyst who witnessed the protests.<ref name=australian2009july11>{{cite news |url=http://www.theaustralian.news.com.au/story/0,25197,25762092-15084,00.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090715095832/http://www.theaustralian.news.com.au/story/0,25197,25762092-15084,00.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=July 15, 2009 |title=Britain offers N-deal as Tehran burns |date=July 11, 2009 |publisher=[[The Australian]] |df= }}</ref>
====July 12==== Judicial System of Iran handed the body of [[Sohrab Aarabi]] to his family. Aarabi, a pro democracy student disappeared nearly a month ago after attending a demonstration in Tehran. His death generated nationwide anger.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://zamaaneh.com/news/2009/07/post_9687.html |title=رادیو زمانه | خبر اول | انتخابات | مرگ سهراب اعرابی در تیراندازی بسیج |publisher=Zamaaneh.com |date= |accessdate=2010-03-30}}</ref>
====July 14==== Ex-prime minister Mousavi visited [[Sohrab Aarabi]]'s home and showed solidarity with his relatives.<ref>[https://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5jGSJEAPs_r2T2wxsL5G3t4z-jajQD99EQKP00 ]{{Dead link|date=March 2010}}</ref>
====July 17====
Nearly two million<ref>{{cite web |author=Behnegarsoft.com |url=http://www.fararu.com/vdch6xni.23n6qdftt2.html |title=پايگاه خبری تحليلی فرارو - جمعيت حاضر در نماز جمعه تهران چقدر بودند؟ |publisher=Fararu.com |date= |accessdate=2010-03-30 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100410122856/http://www.fararu.com/vdch6xni.23n6qdftt2.html |archivedate=2010-04-10 |df= }}</ref> people demonstrated in the streets of Tehran and joined the Friday Prayer sermon of Mr Hashemi Rafsanjani.<ref>{{cite web|author=Copyright: gooya.com 2009 |url=http://news.gooya.com/politics/archives/2009/07/090860.php |title=gooya news :: politics : استقبال بی‌سابقه مردم تهران از نماز جمعه امروز (همراه با فيلم)، ايلنا |publisher=News.gooya.com |date= |accessdate=2010-03-30}}</ref> Leading reformist leaders Mir Hossein Mousavi and Mehdi Karroubi also took part in the gatherings as announced before. Police used tear gas against the crowd. At least 15 people have been arrested by the police. Among the arrested protestors were [[Shadi Sadr]], a prominent Iranian women rights activist and writer.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://zamaaneh.com/news/2009/07/post_9756.html|title=شادی صدر بازداشت شد}}</ref> Deutsche Welle described it as the most critical and turbulent Friday prayer in the history of contemporary Iran.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dw-world.de/dw/article/0,,4496564,00.html?maca=per-rss-per-all-1491-rdf |title=اعتراضی‌ترین نمازجمعه‌ی تاریخ معاصر ایران | • ایران | Deutsche Welle | 17.07.2009 |publisher=Dw-world.de |date= |accessdate=2010-03-30}}</ref>
[[Mehdi Karroubi]] and [[Abdollah Nouri]] were attacked and beaten by men in plain-clothes on his way to Friday prayers at Tehran university.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5jKg82GeI0ieEWIag02QA5W98xbwA|title=Iran's Karroubi attacked on way to prayers: website}}</ref> A day before, Sajjad Saffar Harandi, the son of ministry of culture of Iran, wrote in his weblog that Mousavi, Karroubi and Khatami will be beaten if they attend the Friday prayers.
In his speech, former president Hashemi Rafsanjani said: "Doubt has been created [about the election results]," he said. "There is a large portion of the wise people who say they have doubts. We need to take action to remove this doubt."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2009/jul/17/islamic-leader-rafsanjani-rallies-iran-opposition/?feat=home_headlines|title=Iran leader Rafsanjani rallies opposition|publisher=Washington Times}}</ref>
====July 18====
Hard-line cleric [[Mohammad Yazdi]] harshly criticized July 17 Friday sermon and stated the legitimacy of leadership in Iran does not come from the nation, rather it comes from God. Such statements has previously theorized by [[Mohammad Taghi Mesbah Yazdi]] and his circle.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/07/19/world/middleeast/19iran.html | work=The New York Times | title=Iran's Ex-President Criticized for Comments About Election | first=Robert F. | last=Worth | date=July 19, 2009 | accessdate=March 28, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Mokfi |first=Mazyar |url=http://www.rferl.org/content/Irans_Ultraconservatives_May_See_Chance_To_Revive_Wilting_Revolution/1768776.html |title=Iran's Ultraconservatives May See Chance To Revive 'Wilting' Revolution - Radio Free Europe / Radio Liberty © 2010 |publisher=Rferl.org |date= |accessdate=2010-03-30}}</ref>
Several Persian-language news websites reported that, the Iranian army has arrested 36 officers who planned to attend the Friday prayer sermon by former president Hashemi Rafsanjani in their military uniforms as an act of political defiance.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2009/jul/19/iran-army-officers-arrested | work=The Guardian | location=London | title=Thirty-six army officers arrested in Iran over protest plan | first=Robert | last=Tait | date=July 19, 2009 | accessdate=March 28, 2010}}</ref>
On July 18, the deputy of the social and cultural affairs of the Ministry of Interior quoted Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, as "demanding the setting up of legal circumstances for making the prison environment more difficult for professional offenders and hooligans and thugs." He stressed that, "Preparations for creating such an atmosphere must be carried out by the Prisons Organization" (Sarmayeh daily, July 19, 2009).<ref>[http://ncr-iran.org/content/view/6805/1/ Iran: Ahmadinejad demands escalation of suppression of prisoners]</ref>
====July 19====
Thousands of people demonstrated in [[Shiraz]]. The event was organized by Mousavi and Karrobi's supporters. In Tehran former president Khatami said that a referendum is the only solution to the crisis. The referendum must be conducted by [[Expediency Discernment Council]] of Iran.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/persian/iran/2009/07/090719_bd_ir88_khatami_referendum.shtml |title=BBC فارسی - ايران - خاتمی: همه‌پرسی از مردم تنها راه حل است |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2010-03-30}}</ref>
====July 21====
Clashes erupted in the afternoon in Tehran between anti-government protesters seeking to mark a nationalist Iranian anniversary (the beginning of day of [[Mohammad Mosaddegh]]'s prime ministership) and hordes of baton-wielding plainclothes Basiji militiamen and government security officers filling a central square.<ref>{{cite news|last=McManus |first=Doyle |url=http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/world/la-fg-iran-protest22-2009jul22,0,3112580.story |title=Articles about Iran - Los Angeles Times |publisher=Latimes.com |date= |accessdate=2010-03-30 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090724190036/http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/world/la-fg-iran-protest22-2009jul22,0,3112580.story |archivedate=July 24, 2009 }}</ref> Several prominent members of Iran [[National Front (Iran)|National Front]] including Dr. Hossein Mojtahedi were arrested by the security forces in 7 Tir square in Tehran.<ref>{{cite web|author=Radio Iran On Air|url=http://www.iranonair.com/articles-%D9%85%DB%8C%D8%AF%D8%A7%D9%86+7+%D8%AA%DB%8C%D8%B1%D8%9B+%D8%A8%D8%A7%D8%B2%D8%AF%D8%A7%D8%B4%D8%AA+%DA%86%D9%86%D8%AF+%D8%AA%D9%86+%D8%A7%D8%B2+%D8%A7%D8%B9%D8%B6%D8%A7%DB%8C+%D8%AC%D8%A8%D9%87%D9%87+%D9%85%D9%84%DB%8C+%D8%A7%DB%8C%D8%B1%D8%A7%D9%86.html |title=میدان 7 تیر؛ بازداشت چند تن از اعضای جبهه ملی ایران | اخبار | Iran On Air :: ایران آن ایر |publisher=Iran On Air |date= |accessdate=2010-03-30}}</ref>
In a new form of protest, activists were urged to turn on lights and domestic appliances that consume large amounts of electricity, such as irons, toasters and microwave ovens at 2055 (1625 GMT) and then back on five minutes later. The resulting surge in demand could possibly cause a power outage and cloak Tehran in darkness, allowing some the chance to protest on the streets.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/8161824.stm | title=Arrests at new Iranian protests | publisher=BBC NEWS | date=2009-07-21 | accessdate=2009-07-22}}</ref>
====July 22–24====
A three-day-long hunger strike was organized and followed by people in several parts of the world.<ref>{{cite web|title=Hamid Dabashi's Official Web Site|url=http://www.hamiddabashi.com/hunger-strike-july-2009.html|work=|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5ic3Vyydk?url=http://www.hamiddabashi.com/hunger-strike-july-2009.html|archivedate=2009-07-28|deadurl=yes|accessdate=2009-07-23|df=}}</ref>
====July 25====
One of the largest protests held outside Iran was organized by United For Iran and held in over 100 cities all over the world.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2009/WORLD/meast/07/25/iran.world.protests/index.html#cnnSTCText|title=Global protests over post-election crackdown in Iran|publisher=CNN|accessdate= 2009-07-25 | date=July 26, 2009}}</ref>
Mousavi, former president Mohammad Khatami, and 67 other reformists wrote and were signatories of an open letter sent to Iran's top clerics saying police have held protesters without charges and that "they have resorted to illegal, immoral and un-Islamic methods to obtain confessions."<ref>{{cite news|url=https://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20090725/ap_on_re_mi_ea/ml_iran_election_7|title=Iran's opposition turns to top clerics for help|agency=Associated Press|accessdate= 2009-07-25}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/07/26/world/middleeast/26iran.html?em|title=Iran's Opposition Calls Crackdown 'Immoral'|publisher=New York Times|accessdate= 2009-07-26 | first1=Robert F. | last1=Worth | first2=Nazila | last2=Fathi | date=July 26, 2009}}</ref>
====July 26====
Mir Hossein Mousavi and Mahdi Karroubi sent a request to the Iranian Interior Ministry to hold a memorial service in Tehran to commemorate the end of the 40-day mourning cycle on 30 July for the people who died on 20 June during the protests, including [[Neda Agha Soltan]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20090726/ap_on_re_mi_ea/ml_iran_election_14|title=Iran's opposition asks to mourn iconic victim|agency=Associated Press|accessdate= 2009-07-26}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref>
A video was brought out of Iran showing many protestors rallied outside of the Russian Embassy and started chanting "Death to Russia" after hearing reports that Russia welcomed Ahmadinejad's victory and was reportedly assisting Riot Police and the IRGC. Several other protests were held outside of embassies of countries that welcomed the results.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://thelede.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/07/20/why-death-to-russia-is-the-new-death-to-america-for-irans-opposition/|title=For Iran's Opposition, 'Death to Russia' Is the New 'Death to America'|publisher=The New York Times|accessdate=2009-07-30 | first=Robert | last=Mackey | date=July 20, 2009}}</ref>
====July 27–28====
A spokesman for Ayatollah [[Mahmoud Hashemi Shahrudi]] condones the arrests of the people during the protests. Mir Mousavi argues back later about the situational comments.<ref name="july27">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/8170847.stm|title=Iran judge urges arrests decision |date=July 27, 2009|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=July 28, 2009}}</ref> The next day, 140 of the protesters during the elections are released from [[Evin Prison]].<ref name="July28">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/8173113.stm|title=Iran 'releases 140 demonstrators'|date=July 28, 2009|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=July 28, 2009}}</ref>
====July 29====
The Iranian government announced that first set of trials for the detained opposition supporters will begin 1 August. The trials would start with the prosecution of around 20 protesters.<ref name="july29">{{cite news|url=https://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20090730/ap_on_re_mi_ea/ml_iran_election;_ylt=AnD1TmA2l44ZCkZwAkSRlwms0NUE;_ylu=X3oDMTMyM2xlbjlvBGFzc2V0A2FwLzIwMDkwNzMwL21sX2lyYW5fZWxlY3Rpb24EY3BvcwMxBHBvcwMyBHB0A3NlY3Rpb25zX2Nva2UEc2VjA3luX3RvcF9zdG9yeQRzbGsDaXJhbmlhbnBvbGlj|title=Iranian police use force against graveside rally|agency=Associated Press|accessdate=2009-07-30|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090802152246/http://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20090730/ap_on_re_mi_ea/ml_iran_election|archivedate=2009-08-02|df=}}</ref>
====July 30====
Iranian people held peaceful demonstrations all over the country. Hundreds of thousands of people mourn the martyrs of Iranian civil rights movement in cities like [[Ahvaz]], [[Isfahan]], [[Shiraz]], [[Rasht]] and [[Tehran]].<ref>[http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/babylonbeyond/2009/07/iran-footage-emerges-from-demonstrations-across-the-country.html IRAN: Footage emerges from demonstrations across the country]</ref>
July 30 morning 2{{nbsp}}am, [[Mir Hossein Mousavi]]'s aides sent out invitation for supporters to participate in the July 30th (Thursday Mordad 8th, 1388 [[Anno Persico]]) commemoration of the casualties of the protests, namely [[Neda Agha-Soltan]]. This day represented the end of 40th-day mourning cycle. The message asks supporters to attend peaceful and solemn ceremony at the [[Mosallah Mosque]] of Tehran, the largest mosque in the city,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://iranfacts.blogspot.com/2007/05/iranian-experience-4.html |title=neo-resistance: Iranian Experience (4) |publisher=Iranfacts.blogspot.com |date=2007-05-14 |accessdate=2010-03-30}}</ref> located in the [[Abbas Abad (Tehran)|Abbas Abad]] district. Before the 6{{nbsp}}pm prayer, main activities took place at 4{{nbsp}}pm at the burial sites of the martyrs, namely the [[Behesht-e Zahra]] Cemeteries, which Mousavi and [[Mehdi Karrubi]] were set to attend. After the service at the mosque, the leaders paid visits to and show solidarity with some families who have lost their members in the violence. This message also ties into Mousavi's earlier message that "religious celebrations are opportunities for the display of the 'Green' movement's creativity."
After arriving to Behesht-e Zahra cemetery, Mousavi was forced by police to go back to his car and leave the site. Basij units were dispatched to halt demonstrations and disperse the crowd. Police forces reportedly used tear-gas against the mourners. Some arrests have been reported by eyewitnesses.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.rferl.org/content/Iranian_Police_Arrest_Mourners_In_Cemetery_Memorial/1788959.html|title=Iranian Police Arrest Mourners In Cemetery Memorial|date=2009-07-30|publisher=Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty}}</ref>
Opposition supporter Mehdi Karroubi attempted to give a speech at the cemetery, but was reported to have been forced to flee the site. Reports also say that several of his aides were beaten and harassed.<ref name="july29" />
Renowned film director [[Jafar Panahi]] and his wife and daughter were arrested at the cemetery.<ref>{{cite web|author=(AFP) – July 30, 2009 |url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5hCiMXWvKwQvIo4JRRP28kB4zLWzQ |title=AFP: Iran 'arrests prominent film director' at cemetery |publisher=Google.com |date=2009-07-30 |accessdate=2010-03-30}}</ref>
[[Ali Reza Tavasoli]], a 12-year-old, was clubbed to death by the Basij after he became separated from his father on the ground of Behesht-e Zahra on Mordad 8th.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-3757738,00.html|title=Report: Iranian officers beat 12-year old to death|accessdate=6 August 2009}}</ref><ref name=theaustralian>{{cite news|url=http://www.theaustralian.news.com.au/story/0,25197,26093533-2703,00.html|title=Ahmadinejad's Basiji run a regime of rape, murder to suppress critics|publisher=[[The Australian]]|accessdate=October 4, 2009 | first1=Martin | last1=Fletcher | date=September 19, 2009}}</ref> Someone allegedly captured the death on video. The video is available on YouTube here.<ref>{{cite web|author=17 juni 2009 |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cXQqWy1ogOQ |title=Video from inside Iran of scene after clashes cause death of 12-year old child |publisher=YouTube |date=2009-06-16 |accessdate=2010-03-30}}</ref>
====July 31====
Mehdi Karroubi wrote a letter to Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani concerning sexual abuse and torture of political activists by Iranian police and Judiciary system.<ref>{{cite web|author=Aug 10 2009 |url=http://enduringamerica.com/2009/08/10/iran-the-karroubi-letter-to-rafsanjani-on-abuse-of-detainees/ |title=Iran: The Karroubi Letter to Rafsanjani on Abuse of Detainees |publisher=Enduring America |date=2009-08-10 |accessdate=2010-03-30}}</ref>
===August===
====August 1====
''See main: [[2009 Iran poll protests trial]]''
The beginning of a series of trials was held. It started with twenty people who were arrested in the protests and would later expanded to over one hundred and included prominent reformists, intellectuals and academics. These trials would be protested and condemned by people throughout the world.
====August 3====
Iran's supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, formally endorsed Mahmoud Ahmadinejad for a second term as president in an official ceremony held to set the stage for the upcoming inauguration on the 5th of August.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20090803/ap_on_re_mi_ea/ml_iran_election |title=Ahmadinejad gets key endorsement as Iran president |accessdate=3 August 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090805210518/http://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20090803/ap_on_re_mi_ea/ml_iran_election |archivedate=August 5, 2009 }}</ref> Mir Hossein Mousavi, Mahdi Karroubi, Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani and Mohammad Khatami boycotted the ceremony.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/nationworld/sns-ap-ml-iran-election,0,689184.story|title=No kisses from Iran's leader, but words of support for embattled president|publisher=Chicago Tribune|accessdate=3 August 2009}}</ref>
====August 4====
Reformist Web sites and blogs called for peaceful protests to be held on 5 August during the inauguration of Ahmadinejad.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.twincities.com/national/ci_12993421?source=rss|title=Iran opposition calls for inauguration protests|accessdate=5 August 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bostonherald.com/news/international/middle_east/view.bg?articleid=1189047&srvc=rss|title=Iran's opposition calls for inauguration protests|publisher=Boston Herald|accessdate=5 August 2009}}</ref>
====August 5====
Mahmoud Ahmadinejad was inaugurated for his second term as president of Iran in an official inauguration ceremony in Tehran. Protests were held outside the Parliament during the inauguration. Protesters marched around Vannak Square and [[Valiasr Street]] chanting "Death to the Dictator".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2009/WORLD/meast/08/05/iran.ahmadinejad.inauguration/index.html?section=cnn_latest|title=Security tight as Iran's Ahmadinejad sworn in|publisher=CNN|accessdate=6 August 2009 | date=August 5, 2009}}</ref> Protesters were broken up by security forces with batons and pepper spray, according to witnesses. Opposition leaders, former presidents Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani and Mohammad Khatami, all of Ahmadinejad's election challengers, Mousavi, Mahdi Karroubi and Mohsen Rezaei and some prominent lawmakers all boycotted the inauguration.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.sfexaminer.com/world/52524657.html|title=Ahmadinejad sworn in as Iran president amid crisis|agency=Associated Press|accessdate=5 August 2009}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref>
====August 12====
Following Mehdi Karroubi's letter concerning sexual abuse and torture of civilians in Iranian prisons, [[Ali Larijani]], chairman of Iranian parliament dismissed the allegation as 'sheer lies', saying that a 'precise and comprehensive' inquiry found no cases of sexual abuse.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.presstv.com/detail.aspx?id=103404&sectionid=351020101 |title=Rafsanjani responds to Karroubi 'jail rape' letter |publisher=Presstv.com |date=2009-08-13 |accessdate=2010-03-30 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100604081618/http://www.presstv.com/detail.aspx?id=103404&sectionid=351020101 |archivedate=2010-06-04 |df= }}</ref>
====August 8====
The [[2009 Iran poll protests trial|protest trials]] resumed. Family members of the defendants and other protesters gathered in front of the court to protest the trials. Riot police attacked the protesters outside the court and detained reformist lawmaker Ali Tajernia's wife.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/news/world/2009-08-08-iran-protesters-trial_N.htm?csp=34|title=Iran resumes mass trial of activists, protesters|publisher=USA Today|accessdate=August 7, 2009 | date=August 8, 2009}}</ref>
====August 17====
Following the banning of [[Mehdi Karoubi]]'s newspaper for publishing Karroubi's answer to Friday prayer clerics and some issues regarding the death of [[Taraneh Mousavi]], protesters gathered near the newspaper office in Tehran. Witnesses say police dispersed dozens of opposition supporters who shouted anti-government slogans outside the office of the [[Etemad Melli]] (National Trust) newspaper. Some demonstrators were reportedly arrested.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.voanews.com/english/2009-08-17-voa44.cfm|title=Iranian Police Clash With Protesters Over Banned Newspaper|publisher=VOA News|accessdate=18 August 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090819061355/http://www.voanews.com/english/2009-08-17-voa44.cfm|archivedate=19 August 2009|df=}}</ref>
====August 21====
After the [[Esteghlal F.C.|Esteghlal]] [[Foolad F.C.]] football (soccer) game, some protests broke out.{{Citation needed|date=December 2009}}
====August 22====
It was reported that protests were organized near [[Evin Prison]].
