Workers in [[Behesht-e Zahra]] municipal cemetery in Tehran secretly buried 44<ref>{{cite web|author=توسط محمد ضرغامی |url=http://www.radiofarda.com/articleprintview/1805648.html |title=[دفن ۴۴ جسد بی‌نام در بهشت زهرا در گرماگرم اعتراض‌ها] - [© 2010تمام حقوق این وب‌سایت بر اساس قانون کپی‌رایت برای رادیو فردا محفوظ است.] |publisher=Radiofarda.com |date= |accessdate=2010-03-30}}</ref> bodies from July 12 to 15 in Plot 302.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/world/la-fg-iran-graves23-2009aug23,0,3229813.story |title=Report of secret burials in Iran brings call for inquiry - Los Angeles Times |publisher=Latimes.com |date=2009-08-23 |accessdate=2010-03-30 | first=Borzou | last=Daragahi}}</ref>
====August 26====
Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei says he does not believe that groups protesting the presidential election results had foreign backing.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.voanews.com/english/2009-08-26-voa50.cfm |title=Iran's Khamenei Says No Foreign Backers Behind Protest Leaders | News | English |publisher=Voanews.com |date=2009-08-26 |accessdate=2010-03-30 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090827125950/http://www.voanews.com/english/2009-08-26-voa50.cfm |archivedate=2009-08-27 |df= }}</ref>
====August 29====
[[Shajarian]]'s new album Rendan-e Mast (Drunken Libertines) was received warmly by Iranian mass and youth and thousands of its copies was sold in the first day of its release. He was a major supporter of the green movement.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/8236031.stm |work=BBC News |title=Iran album strikes web protest note |date=September 4, 2009 |accessdate=March 28, 2010 |first=Arash |last=Ahmadi}}</ref>
===September===
====September 2====
[[Sadeq Larijani]] appointed [[Saeed Mortazavi]] to the post of deputy prosecutor general of Iran. Mortazavi was prosecutor general of Tehran for more than seven years during which he was involved in murdering and torturing a number of Iranian civilians and activists including those who were arrested during post election unrests.
====September 4====
Detailed information of 72 victims was released by reformists.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.emruz.info/ShowItem.aspx?ID=23996&p=1 |title=امروز: نوروز منتشر كرد: اسامی و مشخصات دقیق 72 شهید جنبش سبز |publisher=Emruz.info |date= |accessdate=2010-03-30}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.radiofarda.com/content/F8_LIST_KILLED_PEOPLE_POST_ELECTION_NOROUZ/1814704.html |title=انتشار فهرست ۷۲ نفره کشته‌شدگان حوادث انتخاباتی - © 2010تمام حقوق این وب‌سایت بر اساس قانون کپی‌رایت برای رادیو فردا محفوظ است |publisher=Radiofarda.com |date=2009-09-04 |accessdate=2010-03-30}}</ref> For the first time in two decades, Hassan Khomeini announced that a traditional religious event that was planned to be held in Ayatollah Khomeini's cemetery was canceled. Top reformist figures including Mohammad Khatami was scheduled to address the audience.<ref>http://www.ilna.ir/newsText.aspx?ID=75252</ref>
Music legend, [[Mohammad Reza Shajarian]] released a song he performed in the context of post election protests and crackdown of civil movement by the regime.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://shajarianfans.com/post/394.aspx |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-09-04 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090907030839/http://www.shajarianfans.com/post/394.aspx |archivedate=2009-09-07 |df= }}</ref>
====September 8====
Judiciary officials entered Karoubi's office in northern Tehran and told him and others inside to leave, ILNA said, adding documents, discs and other material were seized. "Karoubi's office has been sealed off upon the Tehran prosecutor's order," it quoted Esmail Gerami-Moghaddam, a spokesman for Karoubi's party, as saying. In another incident, Judiciary officials arrested Mousavi's top advisor Alireza Beheshti.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/latestCrisis/idUSDAH842579 |title=Iran shuts reformer Karoubi's office, detains aide |publisher=Reuters |date= September 8, 2009|accessdate=2010-03-30}}</ref>
====September 13====
People demonstrated in Qom after [[Yousef Sanei]]'s speech.{{Citation needed|date=December 2009}}
====September 18====
On [[International Quds Day|Quds Day]], an annual day of solidarity with the [[Palestinians]], tens of thousands to one half million of protesters<ref name="Lemonde.fr 09 18">{{Cite web|url=http://www.lemonde.fr/asie-pacifique/article/2009/09/19/l-opposition-iranienne-reaffirme-son-existence-lors-de-la-journee-d-al-qods_1242479_3216.html|title=L'opposition iranienne réaffirme son existence lors de la journée d'Al-Qods|author=Marie-Claude Decamps|date=2009-09-18|publisher=Lemonde.fr|postscript=.}}</ref><ref>[http://cosmos.bcst.yahoo.com/up/player/popup/?rn=3906861&cl=15644010&ch=4226714&src=news Reuters Video]</ref> took part in a mass rally despite a warning by [[Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps|Revolutionary Guard]] against the demonstration of opposition supporters in Friday. Demonstrations took place in several locations in [[Tehran]] and other cities including [[Tabriz]], [[Qom]], [[Esfahan]], [[Mashhad]], [[Shiraz]], [[Rasht]], [[Booshehr]], [[Ahvaz]], and [[Kermanshah]]. This would be the first major protest since 17 July.
Mir Hossein Mousavi and other opposition leaders called people to participate in a mass protests against tyrants, both Iranian and non Iranian ones. Mousavi suggested the following to be chanted:<ref>{{cite web|author=Copyright: gooya.com 2009 |url=http://news.gooya.com/politics/archives/2009/09/093728.php |title=gooya news :: politics : شعار پيشنهادی ميرحسين موسوی برای روز قدس، رسانه سبز |publisher=News.gooya.com |date= |accessdate=2010-03-30}}</ref>
تفنگت را زمين بگذار که من بيزارم از ديدار اين خونبار چه در غزه - چه در لبنان چه در قدس و چه در ايران
(Put down your gun, because I hate to see that blood-thirsty thing, be it in Gaza, or Lebanon, in Quds or Iran)(based on a poem by [[Fereydoon Moshiri]])
People wearing [[Iranian Green Movement|green]] accessories also chanted "Neither [[Gaza Strip|Gaza]] nor [[Lebanon]], I sacrifice my life for Iran" and "Torture and rape are not effective any more". "Liar, where is your 63%?" was also shouted.<ref name="Lemonde.fr 09 18" /> Former president [[Mohammad Khatami]] who was among the protesters, was attacked by the son of ultra-conservative [[Hossein Shariatmadari]], and sporadic fights broke out between the protesters and security forces. Tear gas was fired into the crowds, where protesters chanted in support of Mousavi. Both Mousavi and [[Karroubi]] attended the rally. As [[Ahmadinejad]] himself gave the keynote speech at [[Tehran University]] renewing [[Mahmoud Ahmadinejad and Israel|comments about Israel]] and [[the Holocaust]], tens of thousands chanted "Death to the dictator" in nearby streets. Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei banned demonstrations on Quds Day, but despite this, top opposition leaders joined the demonstrations. At least ten people were arrested during the demonstrations.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20090918/ap_on_re_mi_ea/ml_iran |title=Thousands march in Iran opposition protests |accessdate=September 18, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090922213911/http://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20090918/ap_on_re_mi_ea/ml_iran |archivedate=September 22, 2009 }}</ref> The demonstrations began peacefully until tear gas was used against the demonstrators. Rocks and bricks were thrown. Several people were injured.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/8262273.stm|title=Clashes erupt at Iran mass rally|publisher=BBC|accessdate=September 18, 2009 | date=September 18, 2009}}</ref>
In its article, Lemonde.fr claim that people's minds have changed, that people are counter-attacking [[basij]] to free their friends, and that the government, facing these several months-long protests, is increasingly losing support,<ref name="Lemonde.fr 09 18" /> while the ''[[New York Times]]'' noticed the leniency of the police.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/09/19/world/middleeast/19iran.html?bl|title=Despite Warning, Thousands Rally in Iran|publisher=The New York Times|date=2009-09-18 | first=Robert F. | last=Worth | accessdate=March 28, 2010}}</ref>
[[File:Handala-edit.png|200px|right|thumb|[[Handala]], coming and watching [[Iranian Green Movement]], has become a web mascot.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/shirin-sadeghi/qods-day-protesters-trans_b_291220.html|title=QODS DAY: Protesters Transform Jerusalem Day Into Iran Day|author=Shirin Sadeghi|date=2009-09-18|postscript=.|work=Huffington Post}}</ref>]]
====September 20====
Iranian actress [[Shohreh Aghdashloo]] wears a green wrist band in support of the reformers at the [[61st Primetime Emmy Awards]].
====September 24====
Demonstrators from around the world gathered in New York City to protest against Ahmadinejad's speech to world leaders at the U.N. General Assembly.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.voanews.com/english/2009-09-25-voa8.cfm|title=Demonstrators in New York Protest Against Iranian President Ahmadinejad|publisher=VOA|date=2009-09-28|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5kDDInsXb?url=http://www.voanews.com/english/2009-09-25-voa8.cfm|archivedate=2009-10-02|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.globalpost.com/notebook/asia/090923/iranians-protest-new-york-because-they-can|title=Iranians protest in New York ...|publisher=Global Post|date=2009-09-28}}</ref>
====September 28====
The Norooz website reported that about 1,000 students demonstrated at [[Tehran University]]. They carried green placards, the campaign colour of opposition leader Mir Hossein Musavi in the June election, and called for detained students to be freed and the government to resign. There were also around 50 members of a pro-government Islamic volunteer militia, the Basij, at the scene, shouting slogans against Musavi.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rferl.org/content/Website_Cites_Antigovernment_Protest_By_Iran_Students/1838581.html|title=Website Cites Antigovernment Protest By Iran Students |publisher=Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty|date=2009-09-28}}</ref> Ahmadinejad had planned to speak at the university but was forced to cancel his visit there due to the large protests.<ref name=nytimesseptember>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/10/03/world/asia/03iran.html|title=Authorities in Iran Arrest 18 Students |publisher=The New York Times|accessdate=6 October 2009 | first=Nazila | last=Fathi | date=October 3, 2009}}</ref>
===October===
====October 2====
The [[Tehran derby]] was watched by about 90,000 spectators and for the sixth straight time ended in a [[tie (draw)|tie]]. The spectators accused the teams of collusion.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.payvand.com/news/09/oct/1019.html|title=Esteghlal, Persepolis tie 1-1 in IPL |publisher=Payvand Iran News|date=2009-10-02}}</ref> They also chanted "Ya Hossein, Mir Hossein" in support of the opposition candidate Mir Hossein Mousavi. The Slogans could be heard on State TV.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7mmPApcjjDA|title=شعار یا حسین میر حسین تماشاگران |publisher=YouTube.com|date=2009-10-02}}</ref> Police had previously warned against any political activity, even cutting off cellphone service in the area,<ref name=nytimesseptember/> and some people were reportedly arrested.
Unrelated to the Tehran derby, 18 students who were part of a pro-democracy movement were arrested in Tehran.<ref name=nytimesseptember/>
====October 7====
The [[Middle East Studies Association of North America]] (MESA) wrote a letter to Ayatollah Ali Khamenei expressing concern over the handling of the election and the following protests. MESA especially condemned Iranian officials for the [[2009 Iranian university dormitory raids|university raids]] and arrest of students.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.payvand.com/news/09/oct/1086.html|title=MESA Letter Of Protest To Iranian Authorities |accessdate=10 October 2009}}</ref>
====October 24====
Basij Militia attacked Mehdi Karroubi and injured him when he attended Tehran's press exhibition.<ref>{{cite web|author=(AFP) – October 23, 2009 |url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5jccoey4CuKeqObpRB9V_w_kT7V-g |title=AFP: Clashes as Iran opposition leader visits exhibition |publisher=Google.com |date=2009-10-23 |accessdate=2010-03-30}}</ref>
====October 28====
An Iranian student and math Olympics champion, [[Mahmoud Vahidnia]], criticized supreme leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei directly to his face for the violence and crackdown on protests. This is normally considered a crime to insult the Iranian leader punishable by a prison sentence.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2009/11/05/mahmoud-vahidnia-student_n_347823.html|title=Mahmoud Vahidnia, Student, Stuns Iran By Criticizing Supreme Leader|publisher=Huffington Post|accessdate=6 November 2009|date=November 5, 2009}}</ref>
===November=== [[File:Protests in azad university of qazvin.jpg|thumb|right|Protests in Azad University of Qazvin.]]
====November 4====
In some of the biggest street demonstrations since mid-September, tens of thousands of protesters gathered in Tehran on the 13th of Aban, a state holiday in [[Iran]] which commemorates the student takeover of the [[Diplomatic missions of the United States|American Embassy]] and the ensuing [[Iranian Hostage Crisis]]. [[Basij]] forces attacked protesters with clubs and teargas. Unconfirmed reports state that the Basij also fired live bullets.<ref name=NovemberFourth>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2009/nov/04/iran-protests-embassy-30th-anniversary|title=Iran protesters hijack 30th anniversary of US embassy seizure|publisher=The Guardian|accessdate=4 November 2009 | location=London | first=Ian | last=Black | date=November 4, 2009}}</ref> Protests also took place in [[Shiraz]], [[Isfahan]], [[Tabriz]], [[Qazvin]], [[Mashad]], and [[Rasht]]. Reformist candidate Mousavi was banned from leaving his home, however Karroubi, another reformist candidate, briefly joined protests at Haft-e Tir Square, according to the reformist website Mowjcamp, but he was forced to flee when he was roughed up by "agitators".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://andrewsullivan.theatlantic.com/the_daily_dish/2009/11/liveblogging-the-revolution.html|title=Live-Blogging The Revolution: 13 Aban|publisher=The Atlantic|accessdate=4 November 2009}}</ref> Several people were hospitalized due to injuries inflicted upon them by the Basij at the event and 109 people were arrested according to Iranian authorities.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.presstv.ir/detail/110690.html|title=Iran says 109 arrested at anti-US rally|accessdate=7 November 2009}}</ref><ref>[http://www.nguoi-viet.com/absolutenm/anmviewer.asp?a=103672&z=5 Cảnh sát Iran đụng độ với thành phần biểu tình chống chính phủ] {{vi}}</ref>
During the official ceremony government supporters set fire to US flags to commemorate the 1979 embassy takeover. The ceremony was televised and, despite Iranian government authorities encouraging people to chant "[[Death to America]]," protesters instead chanted "Death to the Dictator".<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/middleeast/iran/6502277/Iran-protests-opposition-clashes-with-security-forces.html|title=Iran protests: opposition clashes with security forces|publisher=The Telegraph| location=London | first1=Adrian | last1=Blomfield | date=November 4, 2009 | accessdate=March 28, 2010}}</ref> Protesters also chanted "A green Iran doesn't need nuclear weapons."<ref name=NovemberFourth /><ref>{{cite news|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/washington/2009/11/irans-prodemocracy-protesters-to-obama-with-us-or-against-us-what-a-difference-30-years-makes.html|title=Iran's pro-democracy protesters to Obama: With us or against us? What a difference 30 years makes|publisher=[[Los Angeles Times]]|accessdate=4 November 2009 | date=November 4, 2009}}</ref>
During the ceremony Grand Ayatollah Hossein Ali Montazeri called the seizure of the US embassy in 1979 a mistake, saying "The occupation of the American embassy at the start had the support of Iranian revolutionaries and the late Imam Khomeini and I supported it too, but considering the negative repercussions and the high sensitivity which was created among the American people and which still exists, it was not the right thing to do."<ref name=NovemberFourth /> Several protests were held online on this day as well.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://advocacy.globalvoicesonline.org/2009/11/07/iran-online-protest-during-the-30th-anniversary-of-the-us-embassy-seizure/|title=Iran: Online protest during the 30th anniversary of the US embassy seizure|accessdate=7 November 2009}}</ref>
====November 22====
Former Iranian [[Vice President of Iran|Vice President]] [[Mohammad-Ali Abtahi]] who was sentenced to six years imprisonment in connection with the [[2009 Iranian election protests|June election protests]] was released on bail. [http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2009-11/22/content_12522098.htm (Xinhua)] [https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5jKFdYEM-BIoe142VJAtBVwwytEaA (AFP)]
===December===
{{See also|2009 Ashura Iran anti-government protest|Hosein-Ali Montazeri#Funeral and protests|Death of Seyed Ali Mousavi}}
====December 7====
December 7 (16 of Azar on the [[Iranian calendar]]) is [[Student Day (Iran)|Student Day]] in Iran ({{lang-fa|روز دانشجو}}). It is the anniversary of the murders of three students from the [[University of Tehran]] on December 7, 1953 by Iranian police under the [[Pahlavi dynasty|Shah's]] rule.<ref>{{cite book|last=Yaghmaian|first=Behzad|title=Social change in Iran: an eyewitness account of dissent, defiance, and new movements for rights|publisher=SUNY Press|year=2002|page=240|isbn=978-0-7914-5211-0}}</ref> People across Iran broke out in protests on December 7, 2009 in remembrance of the murder and protests on this day in 1953, as well as the [[Iran student protests, July 1999|student protests in July 1999]]. The protests in July 1999 were, at that time, the most widespread public protests to occur in Iran since the [[Iranian Revolution]].<ref>Ebadi, Shirin, ''Iran Awakening'', by Shirin Ebadi with Azadeh Moaveni, Random House New York, 2006, p.149</ref> However, the 2009 election protests have surpassed the 1999 protests to become the largest protests in Iran since the Iranian Revolution.
Thousands of university students in Iran turned a student rally into anti-government protests. Security forces and militiamen clashed with thousands of protesters shouting "death to the dictator" outside Tehran University. The night before the protests, rooftop cries of "Allahu akbar" or "God is great" and "death to the dictator" were heard from many parts of Tehran in support of the opposition. The rooftop chants — which were almost every night in the weeks following the election — had not been heard since the November protest.<ref>[https://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20091207/ap_on_re_mi_ea/ml_iran_26 ]{{Dead link|date=March 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2009/WORLD/meast/12/07/iran.protest.warnings/index.html?eref=edition |title=Iran police clash with protesters - CNN.com |publisher=Edition.cnn.com |date=2009-12-07 |accessdate=2010-03-30}}</ref> Protests were held at most universities across the country, with the largest at University of Tehran, Amirkabir University, Khajeh Nasir University, Kerman University, Sharif University in Tehran, Azad University, Azad University of Qazvin, and Mashhad University.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.payvand.com/news/09/dec/1069.html|title=Videos: Iran Students Stage Nationwide Protests |publisher=Payvand|accessdate=7 December 2009}}</ref> These would be the largest protests in Iran since November 4, 2009. [[Ayatollah Ali Khamenei]] blamed the United States and Britain for the protests<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.payvand.com/news/09/dec/1064.html|title=Iran's Supreme Leader Blames West for Student Protests |publisher=Payvand Iran News|accessdate=7 December 2009}}</ref> At a speech in [[Mashhad]], Former Iranian President Ali Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani criticized the Iranian government's actions, quoting a verse from the Quran: "A secure society is a society that is pious and not subject to tyranny."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2009/WORLD/meast/12/06/iran.protest.warnings/index.html?section=cnn_latest|title=Iran prepares for Students Day protests|publisher=CNN|accessdate=7 December 2009 | date=December 6, 2009}}</ref> According to reports, more than 200 people were arrested during the Students' Day protests and many were injured.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB126032215259182881 |title=Iran Protest Continues, Under Siege - WSJ.com |publisher=Online.wsj.com |date=2009-12-09 |accessdate=2010-03-30}}</ref>
====December 19====
One of the most influential members of the Green Movement, [[Ayatollah]] [[Montazeri|Hossein Ali Montazeri]], dies. The government have denied any involvement with the senior cleric's death and Montazeri's son has been claimed to have stated his father died of natural causes.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/middle_east/8423046.stm | work=BBC News | title=Top dissident Iranian cleric dies | date=December 20, 2009 | accessdate=March 28, 2010}}</ref><ref name=BBCDec19>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/8433991.stm|title=Iran reformist Mousavi's nephew 'got death threats'|publisher=BBC|accessdate=December 29, 2009 | date=December 29, 2009}}</ref>
====December 21==== [[File:The funeral of Grand Ayatollah Hosein-Ali Montazeri-2009-1.jpg|thumb|The funeral of Grand Ayatollah [[Hussein-Ali Montazeri]]]]
Hundreds of thousands of people attended the funeral of the Iranian cleric Grand Ayatollah [[Hossein Ali Montazeri]] in Qom. He was a major critic of Mahmoud Ahmadinejad who died of an illness on December 19.<ref>{{cite web|last=Hafezi |first=Parisa |url=https://vancouversun.com/news/Protests+mark+funeral+dissident+Iranian+cleric/2364991/story.html |title=Protests mark funeral of dissident Iranian cleric |publisher=Vancouversun.com |date=2009-12-21 |accessdate=2010-03-30}}</ref> Hundreds of thousands of protesters wore green in support of the opposition. There would be major protests across Iran, which led the Iranian government to crack down by establishing martial law in [[Najafabad]] a week later.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2009/dec/21/iran-funeral-ayatollah-montazeri-protest | work=The Guardian | location=London | title=Funeral of Iranian cleric Montazeri turns into political protest | first=Robert | last=Tait | date=December 21, 2009 | accessdate=March 28, 2010}}</ref>
On December 21, 2009, CNN broadcast an interview with a former Basij militiaman, identified only as Seyed (who had fled from Iran), who admitted that the Basij did indeed rig the results of the votes (under the pretext that it was the Supreme Leader's wish for Ahmadinejad to be president, and henceforth God's wish and fulfilling this was a duty for God), by placing votes requested by the disabled and the illiterate for Ahmadinjad, not counting votes for Mousavi at all, confirmed allegations of ballot box stuffing. They were made to attack protesters on the street with various weapons with no mercy and no separation between young and old or men and women. He also confirmed reports that there was torture and rape of both men and women of various ages inside Iran's prisons and the authorities had not only done nothing to prevent this but had encouraged this as well.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/video/#/video/world/2009/12/20/hilsum.iran.basij.speaks.itn |title=Video - Breaking News Videos from |publisher=CNN.com |date= |accessdate=2010-03-30}}</ref>
====December 22====
Protests continued in Qom and clashes between security forces and protesters were reported.<ref name=BBCDec19 />
====December 23====
A memorial was held in honor of Montazeri in the city of [[Isfahan]]. Clashes occurred between Basiji militia and people attending the memorial.<ref name=BBCDec19 />
====December 24====
Mohammad Mehdi Heidarian, the president of the [[Iranian Academy of the Arts]], and Reza Moradi Ghiasabadi, a researcher at the academy, resigned from their positions in protest at the firing of pro-reform leader, Mir Hossein Mousavi. Another 30 people threatened to resign in solidarity.<ref>{{cite web |author=Updated: Thursday, December 24, 2009 |url=http://televisionwashington.com/floater_article1.aspx?lang=en&t=floater_censoredculture&id=16747 |title=Two members of Iran arts academy resign in protest - WashingtonTV تلویزیون واشنگتن |publisher=Televisionwashington.com |date=2009-12-24 |accessdate=2010-03-30 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100102053718/http://televisionwashington.com/floater_article1.aspx?lang=en&t=floater_censoredculture&id=16747 |archivedate=January 2, 2010 |df= }}</ref>
The Iranian government reportedly banned any more memorial services for Montazeri except in his birthplace and Qom.<ref name=BBCDec19 />
====December 26====
Protests erupted when Basiji militiamen barged into the [[Jamkaran|Jamkaran mosque]] in Tehran, where reformist Mohammad Khatami was delivering a speech.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/babylonbeyond/2009/12/iran-video-footage-of-ashura-protests-emerge-online.html |title=IRAN: Reports, video footage from Ashura protests emerge on the Internet | Babylon & Beyond | Los Angeles Times |publisher=Latimesblogs.latimes.com |date=2009-12-27 |accessdate=2010-03-30}}</ref> Protests and clashes with security police occurred in several different cities in Iran.<ref name=BBCDec19 />
====December 27====
[[File:3ashoraie sabz.jpg|thumb|right|Protesters in Tehran on December 27, 2009]] {{Main|2009_Ashura protests}}
Major protests broke out when hundreds of thousands of opposition supporters protested in Tehran and across the country of Iran.<ref>{{cite web|author=Dareini, Ali Akbar|url=https://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20091227/ap_on_re_mi_ea/ml_iran|title=Witnesses: Iran police fire on protesters; 4 dead|publisher=[[Yahoo! News]]+accessdate=27 December 2009}}</ref><ref>"[http://lite.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/HAF751382.htm Iran website says Mousavi nephew killed in clashes]", [[Reuters]] AlertNet. Retrieved 27 December 2009.</ref> This day was the [[Day of Ashura]], which marks the death of Imam Hussain and is an important day on the Shiite calendar. Police fired upon protesters and used tear gas. State TV reported that 15 people died this day, yet official reports from the Iranian government put the death toll at 8, making this the deadliest day of the protests since June.<ref name=BBCDec19 /><ref>{{cite news|last=New |first=The |url=http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/nationworld/2010611314_iran28.html |title=Nation & World | 10 reportedly killed in Iran protests | Seattle Times Newspaper |publisher=Seattletimes.nwsource.com |date= December 27, 2009|accessdate=2010-03-30}}</ref> Among those killed was [[Death of Seyed Ali Mousavi|Seyed Ali Mousavi]], the nephew of Mir-Hossein Mousavi. At least 300 people were arrested.<ref name=Dec27BBC /> [[BBC]] called the protests "the worst violence since last June's contested presidential elections."<ref name=Dec27BBC>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/8432100.stm | work=BBC News | title=Iran protesters in fresh clashes | date=December 28, 2009 | accessdate=March 28, 2010}}</ref> Witnesses claim that the Basiji militia fired live bullets into the crowd. Although it was reported that many policemen refused to shoot on protesters.<ref>[http://www.lemonde.fr/proche-orient/portfolio/2009/12/27/violents-affrontements-entre-opposants-et-policiers_1285286_3218.html#ens_id=1190750] [http://www.lemonde.fr/proche-orient/article/2009/12/27/plusieurs-morts-au-cours-des-manifestations-a-teheran_1285283_3218.html#ens_id=1190750 Selon l'opposition, plusieurs manifestants ont été tués à Téhéran dont un parent de Moussavi]</ref> There was claims that some of the Basiji militia were wearing green caps (green being the color of the opposition movement) and refusing to detain the protesters.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.globalpost.com/dispatch/middle-east/091227/iran-riots-ashura-festival |title=Iran | Politics | Riots |publisher=Globalpost.com |date=2009-12-27 |accessdate=2010-03-30}}</ref> Protesters chanted "This month is a month of blood."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,1950176,00.html|title=On a Holy Day, Protest and Carnage in Tehran|publisher=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]|accessdate=27 December 2009 | date=December 28, 2009}}</ref> A police depot was seized.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/dispatch/2009/12/27/protesters-capture-tehran-police-depot/|title=Protesters Capture Tehran Police Depot|publisher=wsj.com ([[The Wall Street Journal]]) | date=December 27, 2009}}</ref>
Anti-government, as well as pro-government demonstrations were reported in [[Shiraz]], where Ayatollah Dastgheyb was said to be hiding in a mosque and being attacked by the Basij militia.<ref name=BBCDec19 /> In Tehran, Iranian state-owned media reported that tens of thousands of pro-government supporters rallied.<ref name=BBCDec19 />
In Europe, protests were held the Iranian embassies in Berlin, Rome, London, and Paris. The European demonstrators were protesting against the violent crackdown on the protests in Iran.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/dispatch/2009/12/28/photos-europeans-protest-at-iranian-embassies/|title=Photos: Europeans Protest at Iranian Embassies|publisher=Wallstreet Journal|accessdate=December 28, 2009 | date=December 28, 2009}}</ref>
====December 28====
Iran declares martial law in [[Najafabad]]. Najafabad is the hometown of the opposition cleric Grand Ayatollah Hossein Ali Montazeri, who died the previous week. The decision to establish martial law came from the protests surrounding his death and funeral.<ref name=tvwashingtondec28>{{cite web|url=http://televisionwashington.com/floater_article1.aspx?lang=en&t=1&id=16788|title=Iran declares martial law in Najafabad|publisher=WashingtonTV|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716204449/http://televisionwashington.com/floater_article1.aspx?lang=en&t=1&id=16788|archivedate=2011-07-16|df=}}</ref> This is the first time since 1978 revolution that martial law was established in Iran.<ref name=tvwashingtondec28 /> Additionally several leading opposition activists were arrested, including three of Mousavi's top aides, two advisers to the reformist former president Mohammad Khatami, Nooshin Edabi, the sister of Nobel Peace Prize winner [[Shirin Ebadi]] (who's Peace Prize had been seized by Iranian authorities earlier in the year),<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/8433464.stm|title=Sister of Nobel laureate Shirin Ebadi 'arrested in Iran'|publisher=BBC|accessdate=29 December 2009 | date=December 29, 2009}}</ref> and two other opposition activists, [[Ebrahim Yazdi]], who previously served as foreign minister of Iran, and the human rights campaigner [[Emadeddin Baghi]].
Seyed Ali Mousavi's body was confiscated from his family in an attempt by the government to prevent his funeral from becoming another anti-government demonstration. Iranian government security forces used tear gas to disperse the protesters that gathered outside the hospital where Seyed Ali Mousavi's body was.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/middle_east/article6969523.ece|title=Seven opposition leaders arrested as Mousavi nephew's body is seized|publisher=TimesOnline UK| location=London | first=Martin | last=Fletcher | date=December 29, 2009 | accessdate=March 28, 2010}}</ref>
US President Barack Obama condemns the violent crackdown on the protesters, and Russia expresses concern at the events, urging restraint.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://en.rian.ru/russia/20091228/157405302.html|title=Russia voices concern over Tehran unrest |date=December 28, 2009|publisher=[[RIA Novosti]]}}</ref> Other Western countries, including the UK, France, and others condemned the violent crackdown on protesters.
====December 29====
Iran has accused the United States and Britain of orchestrating the violent demonstrations on the 27th. A spokesman for Iran's Foreign Ministry has said the US and UK had "miscalculated" in the governments response to protests that led to more than 1,500 arrests.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/12/30/world/middleeast/30iran.html|title=Iran Lashes Out at West Over Protests |last=Fathi|first=Nazila|date=December 29, 2009|publisher=The New York Times}}</ref>
====December 30==== {{Main|December 30, 2009 pro-government rally in Iran}} Pro-government rallies take place in several cities to protest recent anti-government demonstrations.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5gzdSHkZl-Vrcllkzr74NnWrIb7eA|title=Iran regime supporters swarm streets|date=December 30, 2009|publisher=[[Agence France-Presse|AFP]]}}</ref> [[NYT|''The New York Times'']] wrote "A witness said many demonstrators on Wednesday were taken to protest sites by dozens of buses and were given free chocolate milk, and The Associated Press said the government had given all civil servants the day off to attend the rallies."<ref name=nyt-30dec>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/12/31/world/middleeast/31iran.html?_r=1&ref=world|title=In Tehran, Thousands Rally to Back Government|date=December 30, 2009|publisher=[[NYT]] | first=Nazila | last=Fathi | accessdate=March 28, 2010}}</ref> Observers differed on whether the rally was a sign of strength<ref name="Leverett">[https://www.nytimes.com/2010/01/06/opinion/06leverett.html Another Iranian Revolution? Not Likely] By FLYNT LEVERETT and HILLARY MANN LEVERETT, January 5, 2010</ref> or weakness for the regime.<ref>[http://www.tnr.com/article/world/the-state-the-opposition-strong The State of the Opposition is Strong], Abbas Milani, January 8, 2010</ref>
Mir Hussein Moussavi's nephew was buried in Behesht-eh Zahra cemetery in Tehran amid tight security in which phones were jammed and plainclothes agents mingled with mourners.<ref name="nytimes.com">[https://www.nytimes.com/2010/01/02/world/middleeast/02iran.html Standoff in Iran Deepens With New Show of Force]</ref>
An opposition news portal, Shahrzad News, claims to have in its possession a leaked order by the [[Supreme National Security Council]] ordering a jet be put on standby to fly [[Ali Khamenei]] and his family to [[Russia]] in case of further strengthening of the protests.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.shahrzadnews.org/index.php?page=2&articleId=2073|title=A jet put on standby to fly Iranian officials|date=December 30, 2009|publisher=[[Shahrzad News]]}}</ref>
==2010==
===January===
====January 1====
During Friday Prayer services in the capital, Ayatollah [[Ahmad Jannati]], a fundamentalist cleric who leads the powerful Guardian Council, called protesters "flagrant examples of the corrupt on Earth" and effectively urged that they be executed as "in the early days of the revolution."<ref name="nytimes.com"/>
In a public statement released through internet and to media outlets, Mir Hossein Mousavi declares he is ready to be [[martyr]]ed for his cause as hardliner clerics in the regime even call for his and other opposition leaders (including Mehdi Karoubi) execution. Mousavi said on his website: "I am not afraid to die for people's demands. Iran is in serious crisis. Harsh remarks will create internal uprising." As a way out of the crisis, Mousavi has put forward a five-point plan to the Government for political and social reforms. But he says Iran's leaders must accept responsibility for the crisis and stop its crackdown on dissent. He's called for the release of all political prisoners, more transparent election laws, and a recognition of the right to protest and a free press.<ref>[http://www.abc.net.au/am/content/2009/s2784149.htm Mousavi prepared to die for his cause]</ref>
Huge protest took place in Mashhad University. More than 200 students of the Mashhad Open University in north-eastern Iran had been arrested, opposition websites reported. According to the reports, 210 students supporting the Green Movement had been arrested in the last 48 hours. The reports added that some of the students were also attacked by radical pro-government supporters and that two female students with stab wounds were in a critical condition. Several students gathered in front of a police station in Mashhad, demanding the immediate release of their fellow students and were further planning a sit-in-strike on Saturday at their university.<ref>[http://www.earthtimes.org/articles/show/301734,report-over-200-students-arrested-in-north-eastern-iran.html Report: Over 200 students arrested in north-eastern Iran]</ref>
====January 2==== <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Copenhagen Iran protests Jan 2 2010.jpg|thumb|right|Protesters in [[Copenhagen, Denmark]] on January 2, 2010]] -->
Protests were held outside Iran in 28 cities around the world in support of the reform movement.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://europenews.dk/en/node/28801 |title=Regime Change in Iran - Rally in Copenhagen | EuropeNews |publisher=Europenews.dk |date= |accessdate=2010-03-30}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://united4iran.com/event-calendar/ |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120730114820/http://united4iran.com/event-calendar/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2012-07-30 |title=Event Calendar |publisher=United4Iran |date= |accessdate=2010-03-30 }}</ref>
====January 15====
Iranian Consul General [[Mohammad Reza Heydari]] in Oslo, Norway resigned in support of the protesters and urged fellow diplomats to do the same.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.upi.com/Top_News/US/2010/01/15/Iranian-diplomat-in-Oslo-quits-in-protest/UPI-56521263614885/|title=Iranian diplomat in Oslo quits in protest|accessdate=16 January 2010}}</ref> Iran has also warned the opposition not to use cell phones or the internet as the government crackdowns more on the protests. Police chief Gen. Ismail Ahmadi Moghaddam says those "spreading the message of the opposition" will be prosecuted and punished.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.publicbroadcasting.net/michigan/news.newsmain/article/0/0/1599975/World/Iran.Warns.Against.Cellphone.Protests |title=MICHIGAN: Iran Warns Against Cellphone Protests (2010-01-15) |publisher=Publicbroadcasting.net |date=2010-01-15 |accessdate=2010-03-30}}</ref>
====January 23====
Iranians around the world demonstrated and commemorated what would have been [[Neda Agha Soltan]]'s 27th birthday.
====January 29====
Iranians around the world demonstrated after the Islamic Republic executed two political prisoners in Iran.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/middle_east/8484478.stm | work=BBC News | title=Two activists 'executed in Iran' | date=January 28, 2010 | accessdate=March 28, 2010}}</ref>
===February=== ; Early February Answering to radicals clerics such [[Ayatollah Ahmad Jannati]] will to speed up executions, Iran's judiciary chief firmly state his opposition, commenting this will as being against the [[Sharia]] and law.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/02/01/AR2010020102052.html|title=Iran's judiciary chief refuses to speed executions|author=Ali Akbar Dareini|publisher=Associated Press|date= February 1, 2010 | work=The Washington Post}}</ref>
; February 10 The Iranian government banned [[Gmail]].<ref name="webpronews.com">{{cite web |url=http://www.webpronews.com/topnews/2010/02/11/youtube-advertises-presence-of-new-iran-protest-clips |title=YouTube Advertises Presence Of New Iran Protest Clips |publisher=WebProNews |date=2010-02-11 |accessdate=2010-03-30 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100217034110/http://www.webpronews.com/topnews/2010/02/11/youtube-advertises-presence-of-new-iran-protest-clips |archivedate=2010-02-17 |df= }}</ref>
; February 11 February 11 being the 31st anniversary of the Shah's regime collapse, the support protest is expected to be doubled by an opposition protest.
In the previous days, governmental forces arrested Khatami's brother as well as his wife, the grand daughter of Ayatollah Khomeini. Willing to slow down uncontrolled email exchanges, they also slowed down internet speed and blocked email services such as Google and Yahoo, while campaigning for a state supported email service.<ref name="NYT 2010 02 11">{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/02/12/world/middleeast/12iran.html|title=Violence Reported as Crowds Gather in Tehran|author1=Nazila Fathi |author2=Alan Cowell |date=February 11, 2010|publisher=[https://www.nytimes.com The New York Times]}}</ref>
On 11th, a massive crowd gathered to remember the 1979 revolution. Clashes were also noticed in areas with reformist protests. Police rushed on Karoubi's car, breaking a window, without injuring him.<ref name="NYT 2010 02 11" />
[[YouTube]] places advertisements on their site promoting new videos of the Iranian protests were uploaded to the site.<ref name="webpronews.com"/>
; February 12 Walter Astrada, Olivier Laban-Mattei and Mohammed Abed are awarded the World Press Photo for a picture they took of Iranian women shouting on a rooftop during the protests.<ref>{{cite web|author=(AFP) – February 12, 2010 |url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5ix_rbwpVssW8cLb0UNKZIcUPIHjA |title=AFP: Iran protest picture wins World Press Photo award |publisher=Google.com |date=2010-02-12 |accessdate=2010-03-30}}</ref>
; February 14 Iran arrested several [[Bahá'í Faith|Bahá'ís]] for their religion, which is banned in Iran despite being originated there, along with opposition leaders, activists and journalists.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www1.voanews.com/english/news/middle-east/Iranian-Crackdown-on-Bahais-Opposition-Activists-Journalists-Continues-84347022.html |title=Iranian Crackdown on Baha'is, Opposition Activists, Journalists Continues | Middle East | English |publisher=.voanews.com |date=2010-02-14 |accessdate=2010-03-30}}</ref>
; February 15 Iranian-Americans marched in Washington D.C. in support of the protesters.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://english.ntdtv.com/ntdtv_en/ns_na/2010-02-15/623861391430.html |title=Iranian Americans Protest in Washington D.C. – New Tang Dynasty Television |publisher=English.ntdtv.com |date= |accessdate=2010-03-30 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100315023939/http://english.ntdtv.com/ntdtv_en/ns_na/2010-02-15/623861391430.html |archivedate=2010-03-15 |df= }}</ref>
; February 16 The unknown Iranians who filmed the [[Death of Neda Agha-Soltan]] were awarded the 2009 [[George Polk Award]] for Videography.<ref>{{cite web|author=Updated: Tuesday, February 16, 2010 |url=http://www.televisionwashington.com/floater_article1.aspx?lang=en&t=3&id=17675 |title=Video of Iran protest death wins journalism award - WashingtonTV تلویزیون واشنگتن |publisher=Televisionwashington.com |date=2010-02-16 |accessdate=2010-03-30}}</ref><ref>[http://www.miamiherald.com/news/nation/AP/story/1482116.html ]{{Dead link|date=March 2010}}</ref>
; February 17 Approximately 1,200 Iranians signed a petition against a law that would limit women's rights.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/02/18/world/middleeast/18iran.html?em | work=The New York Times | title=Iranians Protest Bill on Rights of Women | first=Nazila | last=Fathi | date=February 18, 2010 | accessdate=March 28, 2010}}</ref>
; February 18 Mohammed Raza Heydari and his family, Iran's former consul general in Oslo, was granted political asylum in Norway, following threats against him by the Iranian government because he quit his job in protest against the repression and violence which occurred during the election protests.<ref>[https://news.yahoo.com/s/afp/20100218/wl_mideast_afp/norwayiranoppositiondiplomacyasylum_20100218131841 ]{{Dead link|date=March 2010}}</ref>
===March=== ; March 16 Violent clashes were reported between Iranian police and protesters after a massive protest was held throughout Iran during the [[Chaharshanbe Suri]], over 50 protesters were reported to have been detained. {{Citation needed|date=May 2010}}
===June=== For months prior, large protests had been planned to take place on June 12, the one-year anniversary of the disputed [[2009 Iranian Presidential Election]].
; June 10 Two days before the planned demonstrations, former presidential candidates and [[de facto]] leaders of the [[Iranian Green Movement|Green Movement]], [[Mir-Hossein Mousavi]] and [[Mehdi Karroubi]] canceled the protests scheduled for Saturday "in order to protect people's lives and property".<ref>[http://www.rttnews.com/Content/GeneralNews.aspx?Id=1331364&SM=1 Iran Opposition Cancels Election Anniversary Rally 6/10/2010]</ref>
Clashes between civilians and police forces broke out in [[Tehran]]'s Enghelab Square at approximately 2:20 PM after authorities tried to arrest young women for "improper [[hijab]]".<ref>[http://persian2english.com/?p=11549 Clashes in Enghelab Square Over Improper Hijab, June 10, 2010]. persian2english.com</ref> As the women resisted, fellow citizens came to their aid while drivers honked in protest. Four people were arrested after backup police arrived. According to witnesses, the police reacted brutally, beating anyone nearby.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://persian2english.com/?p=11549|title=Clashes in Enghelab Square Over Improper Hijab|date=June 10, 2010|publisher=Persian2english.com}}</ref>
; June 11 On the day before the anniversary many Iranians reported receiving a threatening text message from the Ministry of Intelligence, stating: "Dear citizens, You have been deceived and foreign media to do their work. If you repeat this action, you will be punished under Islamic law."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://enduringamerica.com/2010/06/11/the-latest-from-iran-11-june-waiting-watching-and-wondering/|title=The Latest from Iran (11 June): Waiting, Watching, and Wondering|date=June 11, 2010|publisher=EnduringAmerica.com|author=S. Lucas}}, citing {{cite web|url=http://www.rahesabz.net/story/17160/|title=ارسال پیامک‌های تهدیدآمیز از سوی وزارت اطلاعات|publisher=Rahesabz.net}}</ref>
; June 12 Several scattered protests broke out throughout the country on the anniversary of the election, despite warnings from the government and security forces against protesting. However, there were no major widespread protests. Minor sporadic protest took place at Tehran's Azadi Square and at some universities throughout Iran.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2010/06/13/iran-protest-anniversary_n_610394.html | work=Huffington Post | title=Iran Protest Anniversary Passes Quietly | date=June 13, 2010}}</ref><ref>http://www.insideofiran.com/en/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=3569:muted-protests-mark-iran-vote-anniversary&catid=42:important-news&Itemid=57</ref> Mir-Hossein Mousavi and Mehdi Karroubi both cancelled planned protests fearing violence.<ref>http://www.insideofiran.com/en/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=3535:warning-against-iran-vote-anniversary-protests&catid=42:important-news&Itemid=57</ref>
===September=== ; September 2 Pro-government mobs attacked the home of Mahdi Karroubi.<ref>http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/38987040/ns/world_news-mideastn_africa/</ref>
; September 11 Hamid Mohseni, the head of Mir Hossein Mousavi's office was arrested by Iranian security forces.<ref name="Securityforces2010">{{cite news| url=http://www.foxnews.com/world/2010/09/17/security-forces-raid-office-irans-main-opposition-leader/ | work=Fox News | title=Security forces raid office of Iran's main opposition leader | date=September 17, 2010}}</ref>
; September 12 Hossein Alizadeh, the [[Charge d'affaires]] and number 2 diplomat at the Iranian Embassy in [[Helsinki]], [[Finland]], resigned in protest of the Iranian government's hardline stance.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://articles.latimes.com/2010/sep/12/world/la-fg-iran-diplomat-20100912 | work=Los Angeles Times | title=Iran diplomat in Finland resigns to protest hard-liners at home | date=September 12, 2010 | first=Alexandra | last=Sandels}}</ref>
; September 17 Iranian security forces raided the office of Mir Hossein Mousavi.<ref name="Securityforces2010" />
===December=== ; December 7 Students protest at [[Amirkabir University of Technology]] in Tehran. They are attacked by the basij and the protest is suppressed.<ref>[http://vodpod.com/watch/5071210-7-december-2010-iran-opposition-protests-amirkabir-university-basij-attacking-students VodPod Video: Iran Opposition Protests Amerkabir University Basij Attacking Students, 07.12.10]</ref>
== 2011 == {{main|2011 Iranian protests}}
===February=== ; February 14 Iran's opposition has called for renewed street protests next week on the back of the wave of demonstrations that have swept across the Middle East. Mir Hossein Mousavi and Mehdi Karroubi, the leaders of the green movement in Iran, have issued a call for what they have described as "a solidarity move to support the protests in two Muslim countries of Egypt and Tunisia" on Monday.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/feb/08/iran-opposition-green-movement-tehran-protest | location=London | work=The Guardian | title=Iran's opposition green movement calls for renewed street protests | date=February 8, 2011}}</ref>

[[The CW4Kids]] | first_aired = August 26, 2006 | last_aired = January 18, 2009 | picture_format = [[1080i]] ([[16:9]] [[HDTV]]) | num_seasons = 2 | num_episodes = 52 | list_episodes = List of Viva Piñata episodes }} '''''Viva Piñata''''' is a Canadian-American [[animated cartoon|animated]] television series. It spawned an [[Xbox 360]] [[Viva Piñata|game]] a couple months later after its release. It is produced by an American company, [[4K Media Inc.|4Kids Productions]] and [[Bardel Entertainment]], a children's animation company in Canada.{{citeweb|url=http://4kidsentertainment.com:80/docs/news/2007-0102.pdf|title=4Kids Entertainment Adds To The Growing Viva Pinata Licensing Program With Three New Licensing Deals|publisher=4kidsentertainment.com|date=January 2, 2007|accessdate=August 26, 2016|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070204032438/http://4kidsentertainment.com/docs/news/2007-0102.pdf|archivedate=February 4, 2007 }} It aired to high ratings as part of the [[4Kids TV]] programming block and later moved to [[Toonzai|The CW4Kids]] before being removed from the schedule on October 25, 2008.{{citeweb|url=http://pinataisland.info/forum/showthread.php?p=232006|title=No season 3 for Viva Pinata?|date=August 14, 2008|accessdate=August 26, 2016 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090227130239/http://pinataisland.info/forum/showthread.php?p=232006|archivedate=February 27, 2009 }} It is aired on [[YTV (TV channel)|YTV]] in Canada, [[Nicktoons UK|Nicktoons Network]] and [[CITV]] in the UK and on [[Nickelodeon Australia|Nickelodeon]] in Australia. The series began airing when Magical DoReMi (aka [[Ojamjo Doremi]]) left 4Kids TV due to TV difficulties on August 19, 2006, and the series began airing on August 26, 2006 Viva Pinata was executive produced by Lloyd Goldfine (''[[Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles]]'', [[Yu-Gi-Oh!]], [[Pokémon]]) at 4Kids in New York and Paul Griffin at Bardel in Vancouver. The stories are edited by [[Mike deSeve]], leading a team that includes the award-winning ''[[Daria]]'' head-writer [[Anne Bernstein]] and ''[[Courage the Cowardly Dog]]'' story editor [[David Steven Cohen]]. The series has ended its run on January 18, 2009 in Canada. [[4Kids TV]] and [[Toonzai|The CW4Kids]] in the United States stopped airing the show on August 2, 2008 and October 18, 2008 respectively, but it continued to air in Canada on YTV until June 24, 2011. ==Characters== ===Main characters=== * '''Hudson Horstachio''': (voiced by [[Dan Green (voice actor)|Dan Green]]) A horse piñata with a green teal body like a pistachio, Hudson is one of the most popular piñatas in the business. As a celebrity he sometimes has to disguise himself when in public. His friends often have to keep his ego in check. He enjoys dancing and making extravagant statements about himself. * '''Franklin Fizzlybear''': (voiced by [[Marc Thompson (voice actor)|Marc Thompson]]) A brown [[grizzly bear]] with purple and yellow stripes. He enjoys surfing, and typically speaks with a surfer accent and related expressions. He is fairly laid back and occasionally has moments of intellectualism. He is not good at lying. He also draws portraits of the other pinatas. In the video game, his surfboard is an item that the player can purchase. * '''Paulie Pretztail''': (voiced by [[Brian Maillard (voice actor)|Brian Maillard]]) A cross between a pretzel and a red-tailed fox, Paulie is a no-nonsense kind of pinata who could easily be considered to be "the clever-cloggs" of the main cast (besides Les) and Fergy's best friend. He shares Fergy's aversion of being sent to parties, though it seems more of an annoyance to him, rather than Fergy's idea of thinking of going to a party as frightening, and frequently avoids them. He seems to be good at cooking as shown from the episode ' Recipe for Disaster'. * '''Fergy Fudgehog''': (voiced by [[David Wills (voice actor)|David Wills]]) A cross between fudge and a hedgehog, Fergy loves candy, but fears parties and Paulie's best friend. He is frequently sought out by Langston to attend parties but always manages to escape his bugcatcher's net. His catchphrase is "Oh, fudge!" * '''Tina & Teddington Twingersnap''': (voiced by [[Kathleen Delaney]] and [[Jamie McGonnigal]]) A two-headed serpent crossed with gingersnap. They share a body, but argue a lot. They have both been shown to have sub-par gardening skills. Despite the fact that they appear to hate each other (after all, they are Brother and Sister), in one episode when they are accidentally separated, they end up greatly missing their other half. Teddington is the worst singer on Pinata Island and for some reason has a refined British accent. * '''Les Galagoogoo''': (voiced by [[Eric Stuart]]) A cross between a [[Galago]] and [[GooGoo Cluster|GooGoo]], Les is smart and dextrous, however, when he speaks, it comes out as high-pitched gibberish. Les ranked second place in the 4Kids Viva Piñata character poll. It appears that the main cast may be able to understand him, but simply ignore him. In one episode, he was able to speak, but he was ignored as he always had been. * '''Ella Elephanilla''': (voiced by [[Rebecca Soler]]) A cross between an elephant and vanilla, Ella suffers from [[short-term]] [[memory loss]], thus contradicting the saying that an elephant never forgets. She enjoys ballet. Because of her elegant moves, this caused Paulie and Fergy to both get huge, temporary crushes on her. They even asked her to a dance, but she forgot they had both asked her. No evidence has been shown that both Fergy and Paulie still have a crush on her, if they do, they are very subtle about it. * '''Langston Lickatoad''': (voiced by [[Mike Pollock (voice actor)|Mike Pollock]]) A cross between a licorice and a toad, Langston operates the Cannoñata. He regularly tries to catch the stealthy duo Fergy and Paulie in order to send them to parties. * '''Professor Pester''': (voiced by [[Michael Alston Baley]]) The main villain of the series. In all the episodes he appears in, he and his Ruffians try to capture and destroy a piñata, (usually Hudson) if not all of them, to obtain their candy. Note that he does not appear to be a piñata. When he had his personality reversed and happily gobbled up all of Fergy's candy, he was scanned on the way to the Cannoñata and found to have no candy. Nor do any of his ruffians appear to be piñatas; an episode shows that they resided on the island before the arrival of Pester and were partially responsible for the failure of his Sours experiment. His catchphrase is "I have no regrets", and he always says it when his plans backfire and he ends up losing. He and the Ruffians are the only non-pinatas from the games to have made it to the show, though to be noted Leafos makes a split second cameo in the theme song right when the announcer states "Welcome to Pinata Island" as the screen is panning over a field. ===Recurring characters=== * Beverly Badgesicle: Hudson's biggest, very obsessive fan. * Cecil Cocoadile: Cecil is the only piñata on the island who thinks Chortles' jokes are funny, causing him to burst into tears laughing. In the piñata world, cocoadile tears make excellent [[fertilizer]], so while laughing and crying at his bad jokes, he is also helping Chortles with his garden. * Chortles Chippopotamus: (voiced by [[Sean Schemmel]]) Chortles has a horrible sense of humor, but fantastic gardening skills. Only Cecil Cocoadile thinks his jokes are funny, and Chortles uses Cecil's tears to help his garden grow. * Dr. Quincy Quackberry: A doctor and [[psychiatrist]] with a [[Groucho Marx]]-like personality. He wears glasses and a tie, and he customarily tells poor jokes. * The Great Bonboon (or just "The Bonboon"): A creature who pretends to be an all-knowing guru to steal candy from gullible piñatas like Professor Pester. He is usually meditating, but when no one is present, he talks to his friend Sid on the phone in his normal voice. Paulie is the only pinata who sees through his ruse. * King Roario: (voiced by Dan Green) The King of Pinata Island. * Mabel Moozipan: She owns a well-kept vegetable garden and despises trespassers. She is friends with Florence Fizzlybear. * Pecky Pudgeon: (voiced by Eric Stuart) Pecky takes photos for the local newspaper of Piñata Island, the Pinata Yada Yada. He loves gossiping about everyone and will go to great lengths to bring in a juicy scoop for the paper. (He makes a cameo in the game taking a photo of Gretchen when she first appears) * Pierre Parrybo: (voiced by [[Pete Zarustica]]) Pierre organizes various activities on Piñata Island. He's also the DJ for a call-in radio show. * Ruffians: Professor Pester's bumbling henchmen who usually ruin his plans, since they don't comprehend orders well. They waddle from side to side in their walk, and they love to prank one another. According to Pester, three are boys and one is a girl. * Petunia Pretztail: (voiced by Sieko Shih) A kung-fu warrior who is friends with Florence Fizzlybear, Francine Fudgehog, and especially Haily Hostachio, and teaches Fergy and Paulie how to find their own "fu" * Prewitt Profitamole: (voiced by [[Mike MacRae]]) A brilliant animal who seems to be the only mechanic on the island and he is a wonder at inventing. He also has a love for soaps, and watches them avidly. * Shirley Shellybean: Shirly is optimistic and always is ready to start a new adventure. * Simone Cinnamonkey: (voiced by Rebecca Soler) Hudson's brisk and resourceful agent. He speaks very quickly, rapidly counting off Hudson's schedule. Sometimes, he seems to want his pay more than Hudson's fame, but he is occasionally shown to care for him in both stern and encouraging ways. ==Episodes== {{main|List of Viva Piñata episodes}} The program has also made the leap to DVD via [[Shout! Factory]] with the release of ''The Piñatas Must Be Crazy And Other Stories.'' This release includes the following episodes: "Cocoadile Tears," "Candiosity," "Queen For A Day," "A Chewnicorn In The Garden" and "Legs.{{cite web|url=http://www.shoutfactorystore.com/prod.aspx?pfid%3D5256969%26sid%3D8D782ABB387B4A14A3D4B7C8649787BA|title=Viva Pinata: The Pinatas Must Be Crazy and Other Stories|publisher=shoutfactorystore.com|accessdate=January 26, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120723101459/http://www.shoutfactorystore.com/prod.aspx?pfid=5256969&sid=8D782ABB387B4A14A3D4B7C8649787BA |archivedate=July 23, 2012 }} In addition, "Lights, Camera, Action" was released in May 2009. This is the second DVD in the series. ==Xbox Live sneak peeks== Two episodes have been released on the [[Xbox Live Marketplace]] as sneak peeks. These episodes were "Chewnicorn in the Garden" and "Horstachio of a Different Colour". The Special Edition version of the Viva Piñata game came with a bonus disc, which, along with demos of Xbox 360 games [[Sonic The Hedgehog (2006)]] and [[Lego Star Wars II: The Original Trilogy]], also contained the "Horstachio of a Different Colour" episode. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20150619094551/http://www.vivapinata.com/ Official website] (archive) * {{IMDb title|0837069|Viva Piñata}} * {{tv.com show|viva-pinata|Viva Piñata}} {{Viva Piñata}} {{YTV original series}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Viva Pinata}} [[Category:Viva Piñata]] [[Category:Fox network shows]] [[Category:American computer-animated television series]] [[Category:2000s American animated television series]] [[Category:2006 American television series debuts]] [[Category:2009 American television series endings]] [[Category:2000s Canadian animated television series]] [[Category:2006 Canadian television series debuts]] [[Category:2009 Canadian television series endings]] [[Category:Animated series based on video games]] [[Category:CW4Kids original programs]] [[Category:YTV shows]] [[Category:American animated television programs featuring anthropomorphic characters]] [[Category:Canadian animated television programs featuring anthropomorphic characters]] [[Category:American children's animated comedy television series]] [[Category:American children's animated fantasy television series]] [[Category:Canadian children's animated comedy television series]] [[Category:Canadian children's animated fantasy television series]]
